sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The continuous depletion of fossil fuels and the corresponding environmental pollution as well as climate change call for the development of green and sustainable energy.1,2 Solar, wind, tidal, geothermal, and nuclear energies are clean and renewable energies, but these intermittent energies face challenges such as being influenced by weather and uneven distribution.3 Therefore, energy storage technology is the key to meeting the demand for pursuing the widespread use of the abovementioned intermittent energies. Electrochemical energy storage devices, such as rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors (SCs), have recently been the focus in electrical energy storage for applications in portable electronic devices, electric vehicles, and large-scale grid storage, due to their performance and cost potential.4−7
With the rapid development of artificial intelligence, machine learning, and Internet of things, the demand for the performance in power sources is largely increasing. Supercapacitors store
charge at the surface/interface of active materials through forming electric double layers or relying on redox reactions between electrode materials and electrolyte ions and can exhibit fast charging/discharging capability within 10 s and cycle for almost unlimited times. They are widely applied in uninterruptible power supply systems, regenerative braking, and hybrid electric vehicles.8−10 However, the gravimetric energy density of SCs is generally in the range of several to tens of watt hours per kilogram, much lower than the currently used batteries, which greatly limits their applications.8 On the other hand, batteries store energy in the bulk form, and the energy densities of rechargeable batteries have steadily increased from several tens of watt hours per kilogram (lead-acid, nickel-cadmium, and nickel metal hydride) to hundreds of watt hours per kilogram (lithium-ion, lithium-sulfur (Li-S), and lithium-air batteries).10,11 However, the currently used commercial electrode materials still cannot completely satisfy the continuous increasing demand in energy density. Electrode materials with long cycling life, low cost, and high storage capacity are highly desirable in all the electrochemical energy storage systems. Nanomaterials are promising in terms of facile and precise design of electrode nanostructures, which can greatly enhance the stability for high-capacity electrode materials. Besides, reducing the dimensions of materials from themicrometer to the nanometer range can greatly increase the kinetics of the electrodes because smaller scales decrease the ionic diffusion lengths. An important milestone to initiate an explosion of the worldwide intense research on nanomaterial design for energy storage is the first demonstration of rational design of Si nanowire materials as lithium battery anodes by Cui’s group,12 which can offer 10 times higher specific capacity than graphite anodes and overcome the mechanical breaking problem caused by the 4 times volume change during charge/discharge. Small size also helps increase the surface area with more active sites and facilitates ion exchange across the electrode/electrolyte interface. In this regard, to further increase the energy density and reduce the cost, developing advanced nanostructured electrode materials, new electrochemistry, and battery systems beyond lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is urgent and necessary. The advent of nanotechnology has brought revolutionary opportunities and spurred the fast development of nanostructured materials in energy storage devices. Nanomaterials, compared to their counterpart bulk materials, have attracted great attention in the past decades due to their unique electronic, photonic, optoelectronic, thermal, magnetic, electrochemical, mechanical properties and various potential applications.13−15 During the past decades, various one-dimensional (1D) nanostructured materials such as nanowires (NWs), nanotubes, nanofibers, nanoribbons, nanobelts, and nanorods, etc. have achieved great development and attracted significant interest due to their unique chemical and physical features and promising applications in light-emitting diodes, lasers, field emitters, solar cells, thermoelectrics, nanogenerators, and electrode materials for energy storage devices, etc.13,15−18
As one important class of 1D nanostructures, NWs are considered as promising materials for energy-related applications due to their ease of synthesis and unique features including high surface-to-volume ratios with large active interface between the electrolyte and electrode, 1D electronic pathways for efficient charge transport, and fast strain relaxation during electrochemically driven volume expansion/contraction.13,17,19,20 The various kinds of NW structures, such as fibers, tubes, etc., mentioned above will be partially ascribed to
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
B
and covered in this review. Until now, a number of NW structures have been fabricated via various approaches including chemical and physical synthesis routes, such as hydrothermal/ solvothermal, sol−gel, coprecipitation, template-assisted, laserassisted catalytic growth, electrospinning, thermal evaporation, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), etc.13,16,17,19 The performance of the NW-based electrodes can be significantly changed if their structures such as chemical composition, morphology, diameter, length, phase purity, crystallinity, and the surface defects can be accurately controlled. As such, to design NW electrodes with improved capacity and cycling stability, it is vital to monitor the size, morphology, and structural changes of NW active materials during the electrochemical reaction and cycling. A variety of NW-based materials or complex structures have been widely studied and used as building blocks for fabrication of various advanced electronic devices with multiple functionalities.13,17,19−21 Except for improving the nanostructure of the electrode materials, Mai et al. also suggested that real-time monitoring of phase changes in electrode materials is important for the development of advanced energy storage devices.22
In this review, we start with the discussion of advantages and challenges of NWs for energy storage, followed by the introduction of various widely used synthetic methods for NWs, mainly focusing on the wet chemistry, dry chemistry strategies, and physical vapor deposition, as shown in Figure 1.
Next, we further demonstrate the recent progress in the use of NW electrode materials for advanced energy storage applications, such as LIBs, Li-S batteries, sodium-ion batteries, and SCs, etc. The key parameters for designing NW structures, such as hierarchical/branched, core−shell, porous, array, and heterostructured NWs, to achieve high energy density, high power density, and long cycle life energy storage devices are highlighted (Figure 1). We also emphasize the development of NWs for in situ characterizations, including spectroscopy, microscopy, and chip-based single NW device operations. Finally, we discuss the
challenges and propose future directions for the applications of NWs in energy storage devices.

sections.heading: 2. ADVANTAGES AND CHALLENGES OF NWS FOR ENERGY STORAGE
sections.text: Different from bulk macroscale materials, nanomaterials with the size down to the nanoscale endow the materials with many unique properties. NWs, as one of the most widely studied nanomaterials, have numerous advantages for energy storage applications such as:5,13,19,21 (1) the NW structure increases the specific surface area for electrode−electrolyte contact and facilitates electrolyte accessibility to the electrode active sites, which increases the material utilization and capacity; (2) NWs provide a continuous path for electron transport and lower the charge transfer resistance, which can improve the conductivity and kinetics of the electrodes; (3) NWs are beneficial for shortening the ion transport pathway as diffusion time is in direct proportion to diffusion length,4 which can greatly increase the rate capability of electrodes; (4) NW structure with small diameter accommodates the volume change and structural damage related to the electrochemical reactions, which helps to alleviate the structural variation of electrode materials upon repeated lithiation and delithiation processes; (5) NWs have large length−diameter ratio, which is helpful to construct a binder-free and self-standing three-dimensional (3D) network for flexible electrodes in energy storage devices; (6) the NW is a good model system and enables a unique and powerful platform for in situ electrochemical probing, which can be investigated at the atomic scale with high resolution and reveals the intrinsic mechanism without external environmental influence; and (7) NWs, as the building blocks, can be easily assembled to form branched, hierarchical, and other complex architectures for various applications. Despite the great advantages of NWs summarized above, there are some challenges for applications of NWs in electrochemical energy storage as well, including:5,19,23 (I) NWs with large exposed surface area induce increased interface side reactions, causing reduced Coulombic efficiency and poor cycling life; (II) NWs are easily aggregated during repeated charging/discharging, leading to increased internal impedance and capacity decay; (III) the compact density of NWs is usually lower compared to their micrometer-sized particles, which results in reduced volumetric energy density; (IV) the electrical conductivity of NWs is lower compared to their bulk counterparts because of a shortened electron mean free path by surface scattering; and (V) synthesis of NWs with controllable size and shape is relatively complex, and largescale production of low-cost NWs for industry applications still needs much effort to develop. In the following sections, we will demonstrate the advantages of applying NWs in different energy storage devices and discuss the strategies proposed to overcome the existing challenges mentioned above.

sections.heading: 3.1. NW Design Principles
sections.text:
Generally, most construction processes of NWs are based on the principle that atoms grow along a certain direction in 1D. The NW fabrication strategies can be divided into two modes: “spontaneous growth” and “space-confinement growth”. As for materials made up by some elements (such as V,24,25 Ti,26 Mo,27 Sb,28 etc.) that are easy to form 1D morphologies, the spontaneous growth strategy represented by the liquid-phase
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
C
reaction is always sufficient to obtain 1D products in most cases. For other materials that can hardly grow into 1D morphology, auxiliary tools such as templates29,30 and molds31 are applied, and these methods are summarized into the space-confinement growth strategy. When applied in electrochemical energy storage, pure phase (single phase) NWsmay not provide desirable performance. For example, materials with low electrical conductivity always show sluggish kinetics, resulting in low capacity and poor rate capability.32,33 Materials with serious volume expansion during ion intercalationmay also show poor cycling stability.34 To solve these problems, some heterogeneous and hierarchical NW structures are designed to achieve higher energy density and power density of the NW electrode materials.34,35 Constructing heterogeneous structures with conductive material coating on the NW surface can improve the conductivity.34,35 Fabricating hierarchical structures such as branch-like NWs is also beneficial to enhance the structural stability.34
The strategies of constructing heterogeneous and hierarchical NW structures generally include one-step and multistep strategies. A one-step strategy means that different materials or structures form the expected structure by an in situ growth process during one reaction.34Multistep strategy always requires a previous synthetic step to obtain the pure phase NW sample as a template or substrate, on which modifications will be further processed.36 The schematic diagram of these synthesis strategies is shown in Figure 2. Which method is chosen depends on the
intrinsic characteristics of the materials themselves. The detailed synthesis methods and examples are introduced in the following sections. 3.2. Wet Chemistry Strategies
3.2.1. Hydrothermal/SolvothermalMethod.The hydrothermal/solvothermal method is a kind of typical spontaneous growth method based on liquid-phase reaction by introducing the selected solvents under specific pressure and temperature to speed up the reactions of soluble materials.37 The morphologies of products are influenced by a variety of possible variables, such as the solvent species, reaction temperature/pressure/time, pH value, and so on.37,38 Compared with other methods, the
hydrothermal/solvothermal method is cost saving, has low power consumption, and is comparatively easy to conduct. By controlling the variables in the synthesis process, many NW products have been successfully prepared, such as Sb2O3, 39 TiO2, 40 H2V3O8, 41 NaV3O8, 42 Na2V6O16·1.63H2O,
43 and so on. Luo et al. used Sb(CH3COO)3, Na3SeO3, and hydrazine hydrate as the precursors dissolved in a specific amount of water and fabricated the free-standing, ultralong Sb2Se3 NWs (Figure 3a).44 In order to investigate the formation of ultralong NWs, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of different reaction times are obtained (Figure 3b−e). The authors concluded that prolonging hydrothermal time contributes to the uniform and long NWs. With the reaction time of 36 h, the synthesized NWs have an average size of about 90 nm in diameter and hundreds of micrometers in length. Li et al. prepared Co3Se4 NWs grown on Co foam through a simple onepot hydrothermal reaction.45 With the Co foam as a current collector and precursor, the Co3Se4 NWs are uniformly obtained on the surface of bare Co foam after hydrothermal selenization (Figure 3f−j). The solvothermal method is also widely used in synthesis of NWs by the utilization of an organic solvent to increase the solubility of precursors which has a poor solubility in water. NWs prepared through the solvothermal process are always well crystallized.46 Liao et al. assembled the trigonal selenium NWs by the facile solvothermal treatment with the assistance of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB).47 With the control of reduction time of SeO2, the growth of trigonal Se NWs is suggested to be a solid−solution−solid mechanism. When the solvothermal time is 12 h, the obtained samples are uniform NWs with diameter of about 100 nm (Figure 4). Zhou et al. conducted two steps of solvothermal treatments to synthesize the interweaved NWs of Na2Ti3O7 homogeneously wrapped in graphene networks. The graphene-decorated Na2Ti3O7 NW architecture presented high porosity and structural stability, demonstrating high specific capacity and outstanding rate capability.48
3.2.2. Sol−Gel Method. Sol−gel is a method to obtain the target product by utilizing the characteristics of hydrolyzing and condensation polymerization of easily hydrolyzed metal compounds in water or a particular solvent, followed by drying, sintering, and other subsequent treatments. Generally speaking, the basic reactions involved in the sol−gel method are hydrolysis reaction and polymerization reaction. The sol−gel method is an effective method to synthesize materials with high specific surface area and can significantly reduce the required time and temperature during material processing.49,50 This method has several advantages as follows: easily controls the nanoarchitecture of synthesized materials and possesses the ability to tailor the structure and function of materials, which make it attractive in catalysis, energy storage, and conversion. Wang et al. prepared manganese dioxide NWs by combining a template and a sol−gel solution containing Mn(CH3COO)2 and citric acid.51 They declared that the length and diameter of MnO2 NWs were dependent on the pore diameter and the thickness of the applied template. When serving as electrode materials for SCs, theMnO2 NWs demonstrate a high specific capacity of 165 F g−1. Similarly, Hou et al. obtained graphene−TiO2(B) NW composites via hydrothermal reaction including graphene oxide and titania gel obtained by the sol−gel method.52 Benefiting from this specific method, the prepared NW composites exhibited high surface area (270 m2 g−1). When applied as an anode for LIBs, this composite electrode displayed a high initial
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
D
discharge capacity of 304 mAh g−1 at 30 mA g−1 and a good cycling performance. In addition, a similar method is also used to prepare magnesium-ion electrode materials. For example, An et al.53
reported a kind of hydrated vanadium oxide NW/graphene nanocomposite which was prepared via a facile reaction and subsequent hydrogel’s freeze-drying process. They found that the existence of crystal water in the aerogel can play a role in charge shielding to boost the Mg2+ insertion kinetics. Furthermore, the porous structure of aerogel could allow easy access of electrolyte into the active material. When serving as a magnesium-ion cathode, this kind of nanocomposite could
possess a high specific capacity of 330 mAh g−1 at low rate and stable cycling of 200 cycles with 81% capacity retention at 1.0 A g−1, demonstrating excellent electrochemical performance.
3.2.3. Coprecipitation Method. As a common method to prepare nanomaterials, coprecipitation is often described as a simple and inexpensive “one-pot” method. This method involves multiple positive ions through precipitation reaction to obtain homogeneous composites. In the past decades, various materials with NW structure such as NiFe2O4 NWs,
54 Fe3O4 NWs,55 indium tin oxide (ITO) NWs,56 and Fe3O4-coated Ag NWs57 have been prepared through coprecipitation. Recently, Yu et al. realized the synthesis of an intact ZIF-67-derivedNi/Co
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
E
oxide shell on a Co3O4 NW array (Co-NA) core through a hydrothermal and coprecipitation process (Figure 5a).58 The nanoflake structure of Co−Co3O4@ZIF-NiCo2O4 could be noticed distinctly in Figure 5b. And the cores as well as the shells were presented as an integral whole in Figure 5c. It’s worth noting that the internal nanopores would not only offer excess surface area, but also shorten the ion diffusion distance, resulting in improved energy storage performances. An area capacity of 3.37 C cm−2 at a current density of 4 mA cm−2 as well as good rate capability and durability are achieved. In addition, the assembled asymmetric SC delivers a high specific energy density of 50.6 Wh kg−1 at a specific power density of 856 W kg−1. Even at a high-power density of 11.1 kW kg−1, the device still has an energy density of 30.2 Wh kg−1. Although the coprecipitation method is simple, inexpensive, and high-yielding, the process may cause inhomogeneous component and aggregation of NWs. 3.2.4. Electrodeposition Method. Electrodeposition is
another liquid-based reaction, in which materials grow relying on the energy provided by the electric field. Utilizing electrodeposition to synthesize NW materials always needs a substrate. Taberna et al. chose a porous anodized alumina oxide (AAO) membrane as the substrate, and the Cu nanoarrays were obtained by direct electrodeposition of Cu2+ into the pores.59
After removing the AAO membrane, Fe3O4 was covered on the surface of the Cu nanoarrays by a further electrodeposition process. Xiao et al.60 also synthesized the CoxNi1−x(OH)2 nanosheets, MnO2 nanosheets, and FeOOH nanoparticles deposited on the NiCo2S4 nanotube arrays, respectively, via a facile electrodeposition process. The morphology of the product depends on the temperature and the concentration of the solution, as well as the deposition voltage, which need many attempts to get better results.36,61 Up to now, electrodeposition has still not been widely applied to fabricate NW materials because of the limitation of the substance type and experimental
conditions. Thus, more effective electrodeposition modes need to be further developed.
3.2.5. Electrospinning Method. Electrospinning is a widely used convenient method to fabricate NWs, including hierarchical NWs, mesoporous NWs, and self-assembled NWs for almost all inorganic materials. In the electrospinning process, the injector head on the electrospinning apparatus acts as the mold to control the product into the NW morphology. To obtain the well-designed inorganic NWs for energy storage, three processes have attracted great attention, which are preparing polymer precursor solution, electrospinning, and sintering. Compared to other fabrication methods, all of the three processes are convenient to modify. For the precursor solution, viscosity and conduction, the two most important properties which can be easily adjusted by changing the ratio of polymer and inorganic composition, show great influence on the final morphology. For the marching process, the receiving distance is usually 30 cm. It takes time for the NWs to arrive at the receiver. Therefore, it is easy to influence their behavior. For the sintering process, there are numbers of polymers with distinguishing thermal properties. Combining different polymers will result in different morphology. Electrospinning shows more advantages over the other methods in designing NW structures, and many advanced electrospinning technologies have been developed by modifying these three processes. However, the disadvantage is also obvious that the whole process is too complex to find the explicit causality from the parameters to the final morphologies. By adding template materials into precursor solution, it is easy
for electrospinning to fabricate mesoporous NWs for materials which suffer from a large volume variation during charge− discharge processes. Usually, the organic small molecule and polymer are used as soft templates, and the silica transformed from tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) is widely used as a hard template.62−65 Metal−organic framework (MOF) additive
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
F
materials added in electrospinning precursor solution were recently developed as a soft template. Chen et al. ingeniously constructed highly porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers by adding ZIF-8.66 In the sintering process, ZIF-8 decomposed and formed mesopores, and Zn metal formed in the nanoscale (Figure 6a).66 Then, the Zn metal separated from the fibers because of its low boiling point. As a consequence, the hierarchical porous structure was successfully fabricated by only adding one kind of soft template. Dual-nozzle coaxial electrospinning is a novel idea to fabricate core−shell NWs generally.67 By applying a coaxial dual nozzle, researchers can pump two different polymer solutions to taylor the cone: the outer one forms the shell, and the inner one forms the core after an electrospinning process. Zhang et al. fabricated core−shell silicon/carbon fibers by coaxial electrospinning employing 15 wt % polyacrylonitrile (PAN) in dimethylformamide (DMF) solution as the shell polymer solution, and the silicon contained PAN combined polystyrene solution as the core polymer solution (Figure 6b−e).68 The NW assembled pattern can also be directly achieved by electrolyte-assisted electrospinning (ELES). Park et al. realized the patterned self-assembled nanofibers by direct electrospinning with the assistance of electrolyte solution which fills in the cavity on a curved surface of a nonconductive substrate as a grounded collector (Figure 6k−m).69 Changing the curves, the self-assembled pattern changes correspondingly as the fibers only deposited on the surface of the electrolyte solution (Figure 6n−u).69 On the contrary, magnetic-field-assisted electrospinning (MFAES) is developed to fabricate aligned nanofibers (Figure 6f−j).70 Before the electrospinning fibers achieve the
receiver, the electric surface charge on the fibers will interact with the magnetic field. As a result, the aligned electrospinning fibers will be achieved on the receiver.Moreover, aligned straight fibers can become wavy but still maintain their overall alignment by simply increasing the flow rate. This phenomenon can be observed in different polymers like poly(D,L-lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA, Figure 6g,h) and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, Figure 6i,j).70
Sintering processmodification is useful to prepare a secondary structure on NWs. Chen et al. synthesized hierarchical carbon nanotube (CNT)/Co3O4 microtubes by adding ZIF-67 in the polymer precursor solution.71 During the sintering process, the ZIF-67 transformed into cobalt nanocrystals which in situ catalyzed the CNTs grown on the surface of the nanofibers using pyrolytic carbon as the carbon sources.

sections.heading: 3.3. Dry Chemistry Strategies
sections.text:
3.3.1. High-Temperature Solid-State Method. Many highly crystalline NWs may hardly be fabricated under hightemperature conditions. Phase transformations and morphology changes will always occur with the increasing temperature, especially at high heating rate and relatively high-temperature level.72 Therefore, the high-temperature solid-state method is only limited to the synthesis of thermodynamically stable NWs. Cao et al.73 first synthesized the carbon-coated MnO2 NWs and mixed themwith LiOH as precursors to undergo a hydrothermal reaction. Then they were heated to 750 °C and maintained for 8 h to achieve the carbon-coated LiMn2O4 NWs (Figure 7a). The MnO2 NWs have a diameter of about 30−50 nm (Figure 7b), which is obtained from the molten salt method. Figure 7c,d show the carbon-coated MnO2 NWs, in which the carbon layer
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
G
is approximately 3 nm. However, the carbon-coatedMnO2NWs have a low crystallinity. After calcination at 750 °C, the prepared LiMn2O4 maintains the NW morphology with a diameter of about 50 nm (Figure 7e), and carbon is uniformly coated on the LiMn2O4 surface (Figure 7g). The HRTEM image (Figure 7f) and SAED (inset in Figure 7f) confirm the formation of LiMn2O4 single crystal. The carbon coated on MnO2 plays an important role in the protection of LiMn2O4 NW morphology, and the LiMn2O4 shows a bulk morphology when bare MnO2 was used. Silicon carbide has an excellent high-temperature chemical stability and can be heated to relatively high temperature. Su et al. used the high-temperature solid-state method to obtain the SiC NWs with highly porous architecture.74 The formation of SiC NW aerogels underwent three steps, including the formation of a SiC NW nucleus, subsequent growth of SiC NWs, and the formation of SiC NW aerogels. The SiC NWs demonstrate ultralow density, high porosity, and excellent fatigue resistance. 3.3.2. Chemical Vapor Deposition Method. Among all
the strategies to produce NWs, chemical vapor deposition (CVD) on substrates has become a common approach, which is inexpensive and large-scale. In the past decade, various NWs such as Si NWs,75,76 Fe3O4 NWs,
77 silicon carbide NWs,78 Ge NWs,79 GaN NWs,80 and ZnO NWs81,82 have been fabricated by the CVD method. Wang et al. presented the first synthesis of single-crystal germanium NWs, prepared by the CVD of germane (GeH4) at 275 °C with Au nanocrystals as seed
particles.79 Adopting the similar approach, Chan et al. synthesized the as-grown NWs with 50−100 nm diameter and 20−50 μm length.83 SEM images revealed that the Ge NWs grew vertically oriented off the substrate (Figure 8a). Crosssectional SEM showed that each NW contacted the substrate (Figure 8a, inset). The as-grown NWs were single crystalline, as confirmed by TEM (Figure 8c). Peaks corresponding to Ge and the Au catalyst were observed using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) (Figure 8e). SEM (Figure 8b) and TEM (Figure 8d) studies found that the NWs became roughly textured but remained adhered to the substrate after battery cycling. Although CVD is an effective and simple method to prepare NWs, the process requires high reaction temperature, and the residual gas may cause safety concerns.

sections.heading: 3.4. Physical Strategies (Physical Vapor Deposition)
sections.text:
Physical vapor deposition (PVD) is a kind of physical method to vaporize the surface of the material source (solid or liquid) into gaseous atoms, molecules, or ions under vacuum conditions and to deposit a film with special functionality on the surface of a matrix by means of low-pressure gas or plasma. Compared to solution-based ways, the PVD method is a cleaner and repeatable method, which has more efficient deposition rate. More importantly, PVD could be used to grow NWs over large areas with good adhesion to the substrate, which can also allow for greater control over the porosity, length, and dimensions of the nanorod arrays. Therefore, PVD is an excellent strategy to prepare NWs. For instance, the growth of tungsten oxide NWs
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
H
on highly flexible carbon cloth through a high-temperature, catalyst-free, PVD process was reported by Zhang et al.84 The tungsten oxideNWs on the carbon cloth substrate have excellent electrical conductivity and thermal and chemical stability, satisfying most requirements as an ideal flexible cathode.

sections.heading: 3.5. Summary
sections.text:
To sum up, this section enumerates the construction process of NWs from different synthesis methods. In the liquid environment, hydrothermal/solvothermal, sol−gel, and coprecipitation methods allow the material to spontaneously grow along the 1D direction, while the electrodeposition and electrospinning methods need a template or mold as an auxiliary tool to control the morphologies of materials. Without the liquid environment, the degree of freedom during the material growth process is reduced, resulting in that the solid-state reaction can hardly form a 1D product solely. Only by precisely regulating the reaction conditions of the vapor deposition process can theNWmaterials be obtained in the gaseous environment.
4. NWS FOR IN SITU CHARACTERIZATIONS When these NWs prepared via various methods mentioned above are being served as electrodematerials in energy storage, it is necessary to carry out real-time monitoring on the changes of physical phase, morphology, and the state of the atomic valence bond connection for the sake of studying the mechanism of electrochemical reaction in the system and finding a way to improve the performance of electrode materials. In situ
electrochemical characterization technologies can directly detect the changes and reveal the mechanism of electrode materials during the energy storage process. Via spectroscopy, microscopy, and chip-based single NW devices, the NWs can be characterized in detail. These characterization technologies can not only provide a direction for the performance modification of NW-based electrode materials but also show great application potential in the exploration of essential mechanisms.

sections.heading: 4.1. Spectroscopy Characterizations
sections.text:
Human beings have been studying the spectroscopy for more than a hundred years, and it is the spectroscopy that has opened the door for people to study materials. Much information has been detected from the inside of materials by using spectroscopy, and great contributions to the research of materials have been made. Because nanomaterials are unstable and prone to change in structure, morphology, and properties during the transfer process, the characterization of NWs under operando conditions is a challenge. In this section, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction spectroscopy, and optical spectroscopy are used to characterize the NW materials under operando conditions.
4.1.1. In Situ X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy Characterization. X-ray absorption spectroscopy includes X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), which is a powerful tool in characterizing the materials. This powerful tool will provide the chemical and the surrounding conditions of the detected element. Characterizing the materials under operando conditions will help us understand the chemical and the surrounding condition variations of the detected element. This is important in understanding the reaction mechanism. LiFePO4 (LFP) is known as the commercialized cathode in LIBs. However, the reaction mechanism is still under discussion. The two-phase reaction happens in this kind of cathode, and the chemical state changes only infer iron. Asakura et al.85 used the LFP NWs to understand the reaction mechanism. They found that the LFP and FP are ascribed to oxidation states of Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively, shown in Figure 9. They further found that very little electron transfers from the O 2p to Fe 3d orbitals. This indicates not only that the reaction happens in the valence state change of iron but also that there is a weak hybridization on the Fe−O bond during the operando conditions.85 Through in situ probing the chemical environment of the element and the position of the surrounding atoms, changes in the structure of the substance can be observed, which will help us to understand the mechanism of the electrochemical process.
4.1.2. In Situ XRD Characterization. During the charge/ discharge reaction, various physical and chemical changes, such as lattice evolution, phase transformation, and structural malfunction, will happen in electrode materials, which impact the cell performance of rechargeable batteries to a certain degree. Therefore, it is of necessity to detect these physical and chemical processes during the reaction, in order to enhance the electrochemical performance of these electrode materials.86
In situ XRD, which is widely used in probing the structure evolution during the electrochemical process as well as the energy storage and capacity fading mechanisms, exerts great influence on optimization and manufacture of better batteries.87 In ex situ XRD tests, the electrode materials are removed from the cells and then exposed to air, and the surface properties of these electrodes will be changed, which will affect the characterization and observation of the electrochemical
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
I
processes. In situ XRD, by contrast, is performed in a closed testing systemwhich avoids the interference atmosphere (Figure 10). For instance, Wang et al.35 used in situ XRD to investigate
the structural stability of the K3V2(PO4)3-bundled NWs during sodiation/desodiation (Figure 11a,b). They conducted in situ characterization on a battery assembled with this material and found that the characteristic peak of this material was shifted back and forth during charging and discharging processes with good reversibility, which also reflected the excellent cycling stability of the material in a sodium-ion battery.
Furthermore, in situ XRD can be tested under various conditions (temperature, scan rate, current density, and so on). For instance, Zhang et al.88 applied high-resolution in situ X-ray to investigate the phase transformation processes of NASICONtype material under different scan rates. From the spectra obtained under different scan rates of 0.5 mV s−1 (Figure 12a), 2.0 mV s−1 (Figure 12b), and 5.0 mV s−1 (Figure 12c), it can be indicated that the phase evolution process is a one-phase solid solution during the desodiation process rather than the traditionally two-phase reaction with high scan rate or low temperature. In general, in situ XRD is an effective method when probing reaction mechanisms in batteries. The useful information acquired from this method is of vital importance to understand the electrochemical process, such as volume change, crystal structure damage, and mechanical degradation. The obtained characterization results can not only explain the degradation mechanism but also help build better batteries.
4.1.3. In Situ Raman Spectroscopy Characterization. The information on molecule structure (mainly molecular functional groups) can be obtained directly through spectral analysis. The Raman spectrum is a kind of scattering spectrum, which can provide inelastic scattering information on vibration, rotation, and low-frequency excitation in materials. It can help the study of molecular valence bond, functional group vibration,
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
J
and rotation energy level transition from the perspective of physical molecules. Correlation spectral data can be used to determine molecule structure and calculate bond energy, bond length, bond angle, etc. as well as to study the phase structure change, stability, surface phenomenon, and reactionmechanism. The conventional electrochemical methods usually use the
electrical signal as the stimulation and detection means, and it is difficult to identify the reactants, intermediates, and products of the complex system accurately and explain the electrochemical reaction mechanism. In recent years, the technique of electrochemical spectroscopy produced by the combination of a spectral method and conventional method has developed rapidly and has become an important means to characterize and study the electrochemical system on the molecular level. Therefore, it is significant to combine electrochemical and Raman spectroscopy to directly detect the structural changes of electrode materials during the cycling process. Actually, with the rapid development of Raman spectroscopy,
the electrochemical method integrated Raman spectroscopy has been greatly developed in the last 20 years. In particular, with the application of confocal micro Raman technology in the field of battery and related electrode materials, researchers have further explored a number of new application technologies, which can better study the properties of battery materials and electrodes. Yang et al. reported the lithiation/delithiation process of a CuNW/Si nanoparticle with various copper current collectors.89
They characterized the vibration of different intermediate products and the structural changes of the Cu-NW/Si nanoparticle during charging/discharging by the Raman and in situ Raman spectrum, respectively. Figure 13a−c shows the characterization of the implant on a copper felt and 100 copper mesh as current collectors during the first charge/discharge process (the mass loading of the two electrodes is 4−5 mg cm−2). The vertical dashed lines demonstrate that the positions of Raman peaks are associated with OC in ethylene carbonate (EC) at ∼714 cm−1 and C−Si at ∼520 cm−1.90 The totally symmetric vibration of the PF6
− anion is observed at∼741 cm−1. In situ Raman spectroscopy was used to investigate the reaction mechanism of active material and the copper current collector loading on the Cu-NW/Si anode (active material). Liu et al.91 designed an on-chip Langmuir−Blodgett scooping (LBS) approach without any binder or conductive additive. Confocal in situ Raman spectroscopy was conducted for directly probing the structural evolution of electrode materials in the battery cycling process (Figure 13d,e). The Langmuir−Blodgett NW (LBNW) energy device provides a great micro/nanoscale battery diagnostic platform to stimulate the further development of NW electrode materials and has the potential to build selfpowered integrated nanochips. These two examples above demonstrate the specialty of in situ Raman in the electrochemical reaction mechanism study.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
K

sections.heading: 4.2. Microscopy Characterizations
sections.text:
During electrochemical cycles, there will always be some morphological changes (including bending and expansion/ shrinkage), and in situmicroscopy characterizations can provide a direct insight/in time observation. Combined with in situ SEM, TEM, and atomic force microscopy (AFM) observation, 1D materials can play an important role in investigating the mechanism of degradation in electrochemical performance.92
4.2.1. In Situ SEM Characterization. In situ SEM is utilized to observe the changes of morphology, identify the element distribution and contents, andmeasure themechanical property. Considering that the cycling life of the electrode materials is closely related with their mechanical property, through the in situ SEM strategy with a microelectromechanical force sensor and a piezo-driven actuator, Boles and co-workers measured the tensile strength and further calculated Young’s modulus of the Si NW.93 After the lithiation process, the elastic modulus and ultimate tensile strength of alloyed Si NW decreased rapidly, which indicated that the mechanical property of the formed amorphous Si layer had been changed. In their following works, the plastic deformation of lithiated Si NW was also observed.94
Since the details of lithiation processes are important for investigating the key factors of optimizing strategies to restrain the capacity fading, in situ SEM characterization was utilized by Strelcov et al. to observe the lithiation process of V2O5 NWs. 95 They constructed 1D batteries based on a V2O5 single nanobelt. During electrochemical testing, in situ SEM characterization was conducted to reveal the peculiarities of subsurface intercalation,
the formation mechanism of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI), and electromigration of liquid. During electrochemical cycling, the V2O5 single-crystalline nanobelt does not exhibit large-scale amorphization/breakage, manifesting only a slight partial deformation, as shown in Figure 14. From all the results, the SEI layer turns out to have a vital influence on the diffusion of lithium ions and further influences the capacity of the single nanobelt battery.
4.2.2. In Situ TEM Characterization. Since the first report of the in situ observation of the lithiation process of a single SnO2 NW inside a TEM in 2010 by Huang et al.,96 in situ TEM characterization techniques have received great attention for revealing intrinsic electrochemical mechanisms. Compared with other in situ characterizations, the in situTEM technique is more comprehensive, which can provide both morphology, structure (combined with SAED) and composition (combined with electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) and EDS) information on the electrodes and thus can realize the direct observation of the ion transport and morphology and structure evolution during the electrochemical process.92,97−101
There are mainly three different cell configurations for in situ TEM observation, including open solid cell configuration (Figure 15a),102 open liquid cell configuration (Figure 15b),96 and sealed liquid cell configuration (Figure 15c).103 Since the sealed liquid cell configuration enables the utilization of commercial electrolytes, the in situ testing can be realized in the case of real battery conditions.104 However, compared with the open-cell configuration, the sealed liquid cell configuration is much more complex, and the implementation is usually limited
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
L
by the experimental conditions.99 Therefore, most of the studies about in situ TEM characterization are based on the open-cell configuration. The open solid cell configuration is the simplest and the most commonly used, in which the electrode materials are contacted with Li/Na metal directly (Figure 15a), and the naturally formed Li2O/Na2O in the surface of Li/Na metal acts as the solid-state electrolyte. However, the open liquid cell uses the ionic liquid as the electrolyte (Figure 15b). Since there is a high vacuum under the TEM, the used ionic liquid must have an ultralow vapor pressure to ensure its stability under TEM. Due to the unique 1D structure geometry of NWs, electrodes with NW morphology are the most suitable for in situ TEM characterization.104 First, compared with other morphologies such as nanoparticles or nanospheres, NW electrodes facilitate the assembly of the nanobattery inside the TEM due to the large length−diameter ratio. For example, it is impossible for a small nanoparticle to be used in an open liquid cell configuration because it may fully immerse into the ionic liquid electrolyte and make it difficult for in situ testing. However, for NWs, this issue can be totally avoided. Besides, NW morphology is more beneficial to the observation of morphology and structure evolution during electrochemical reaction. The NW has a regular morphology, and the length and diameter can be easily and exactly measured under TEM, which makes it facile to investigate the structure change before and after lithiation/ sodiation based on the elongation/expansion/bending of the NWs (Figure 15d).96 Due to that, large numbers of NW electrodes based on conversion or alloying reaction with large
volume change have been investigated by in situ TEM characterization, such as SnO2 NWs (Figure 15d),
96 Si NWs,105 Ge NWs,106 ZnO NWs,107 ZnSb NWs,108 and so on. Table 1 summarizes the NW electrodes investigated by in situ TEM measurements in the past years together with the main obtained insights based on the in situ characterization. We know that NW electrodes for in situ TEM characterization have made significant contributions to the fields of electrochemical energy storage in the past years. Based on these studies, many deep insights and understandings during the electrochemical reaction have been discovered, and the intrinsic reaction mechanisms of some electrode materials have been revealed. Note that the investigation scope based on in situ TEM characterization also has expanded greatly. The studies at present are not only limited to LIBs but also expanded to Na-ion batteries and other systems. Especially, a recent investigation has realized the in situ investigation of the oxygen reduction reactions in solid-state sodium oxygen batteries using CuO NWs as the air cathode under an oxygen environment in TEM.109 With further development, we believe more inspiring results and deeper understandings will be obtained based on NWs for in situ TEM characterization.

sections.heading: 4.3. Chip-Based Single NW Device Characterization
sections.text:
The unique geometry and physicochemical properties of NWs endow great potential for in situ observation. In a chip-based nanodevice, a single NW is wired up into a microcircuit, and a precise measurement of electric signal from a single NW in an
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
M
electrochemical environment is realized. Based on this point, single NW based energy storage devices, such as a single NW battery and single NW SC, are fabricated and studied. These devices give opportunities for the investigation of the property evolution process and explore the mechanism for performance degradation or enhancement. The key features of single NW devices can be concluded as
follows: (1) Single NW devices can simulate a similar work condition as a real energy device for a single NW battery or SC, which enables the precise and meaningful measurement of a single nanomaterial. (2) Single NW devices can be well designed; typical interfaces and locations of NWs can be selectively exposed; and the special electrochemical reaction can be controlled. (3) Chip-based devices can be combined with advanced characterization methods. Typically, these features make single NW devices become a powerful tool for in situ observation and diagnosis. Herein, the recent progress of chipbased single NW devices for batteries and SCs is concluded and presented. 4.3.1. Single NW Batteries. The single NW battery with a
well-designed metal pattern has been developed into a diagnostic tool, which allows construction of the direct correlation among electrochemical performance, structural evolution, and electrical transport. Different from the traditional coin battery, the single NW battery can collect a more accurate signal than that contributed from the single NW electrode without influence from the additives. Combining the ex situ and in situ probing technologies, the change of properties of the NW can be observed during the electrochemical processes.137 The Mai group established an original universal model for in situ
characterization of the electrochemical processes in the materials using a single NW device. As shown in Figure 16a, a unique platform for in situ probing the conductance change of the NW was constructed by Mai et al. on an all-solid-single NW electrochemical device.138 In this device, a single vanadium oxide NW was connected with micrometal electrodes as a cathode by conventional e-beam lithography. For the deposition method, polymer (poly(ethylene oxide), PEO) was used as a solid-state electrolyte, and a highly ordered pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) flake was used as an anode. Based on this, the underlying mechanism of the capacity fading of the vanadium oxide and Si NW was studied by operating the charge and discharge processes (Figure 16b,c). It is found that the vanadium oxide shows a restorable conductance with shallow discharge and charge, indicating a reversible structure change of the vanadium oxide NW. However, the structure change was irreversible after a deep discharge process, which can be understood by that the structure of the vanadium oxide NWwas destroyed by the overintercalation of Li ions. Different from the vanadium oxide NW, the Si NW shows a monotonous decrease of conductance on both the shallow and deep charge/discharge processes. The structure degradation of the single Si NW was studied via Raman mapping. The result was consistent with the ex situ characterization results.114,137 An on-chip microelectrode LIB combining with TEM was also designed to study the lithiation and electrochemical processes of the LixMnO2 and MoS2.
139−142 As an extended research work, Xu et al. designed a single H2V3O8 NW device to investigate the conductance change of the NW that was introduced by the insertion/ desertion of the Li and Na ions in its layered structure.143 Four

4.3.2. Single NW SCs. SCs are considered to be promising candidates for electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices in future generations due to high power density and long cycle life.145,146 Enormous efforts were devoted to improving the
