Hu and coworkers144 built an in situ single NW monitoring platform of MnO2/PGO NW, pure MnO2 NWs, and MnO2/rGO NW to explore the capacitance, ion diffusion, electron transport process, and charge storage mechanism (Figure 16d,e). Typically, MnO2/PGO can be easily obtained by treating the MnO2/rGO with hydrazine hydrate. In this device, a single NW and gold microelectrode are used as working and counter electrodes. TheMnO2/PGONWshows better areal capacitance of 104 nF μm−2 at a scan rate of 20 mV s−1, which is 2.8 and 4.0 times higher than for the MnO2 NW and MnO2/rGO NW, respectively. It illustrated that the rGO would greatly accelerate the rate of electron transport but decrease the ion diffusion coefficient due to the shielding effect of graphene. When fabricating pores in the graphene, the ion diffusion coefficient is regained, which demonstrated that the better capacitance performance induced by porous graphene was attributed to the increase of intercalation capacitance. Hence, such an in situ monitoring platform is an effective tool to detect the mechanism of the electrochemical process of SCs.

sections.heading: 4.4. Summary
sections.text: In this section, we first discussed the in situ X-ray absorption and X-ray diffraction, which will uncover the reaction mechanism. To see the micro- or nanomorphology changes, the utilization of SEM and TEM is inevitable. Also, in order to characterize the physical or chemical properties in the nanoscale, a chip-based single NW is a suitable tool. So, the in situ characterization of multiple aspects will play a big role in the electrochemical process. In the further combination of these, in situ tools will play a more and more important role in characterizing the materials.

sections.heading: 5.1. Brief Introduction of LIBs and Challenges Facing LIBs
sections.text:
Since the commercialization of LIBs by Sony in 1991, LIBs have dominated the consumer markets for decades due to their relatively high volumetric and gravimetric energy density, low self-discharging rate, long cycle life, and low cost.1,4,151 Currently, the broadly used LIBs are comprised of a layered LiCoO2 cathode, graphite anode, polymer separator, and nonaqueous liquid electrolyte. The working principle of LIBs is as follows: during the charging process, Li ions are extracted from the LiCoO2 host, pass through the separator and electrolytes, and intercalate into the layers of graphite to realize the storage of energy, while the electrons pass across the external circuit.152 As for discharging, the above process is reversed. Meanwhile, in an ideal case, lithium ions are reversibly intercalated/deintercalated from the electrodes with 100% Coulombic efficiency.6 However, side reactions that occur during the charge/discharge process consume lithium, leading to a Coulombic efficiency lower than 100% and gradual capacity decay. Thus, the development of a robust and chemically stable SEI is the premise and critical for developing advanced batteries. LIBs based on the LiCoO2/graphite system deliver an output voltage of 3.7 V and an energy density of about 150−200 Wh kg−1.153 However, the currently used electrode materials are approaching their capacity limit based on the intercalation reaction and are still far short of meeting the needs of future
applications.11 In order to cater to the fast-growing requirement of developing high energy density rechargeable batteries for portable electronic devices, smart grids, and electric vehicles, development of advanced electrode materials is essential.153 Therefore, great efforts have been devoted to searching for highcapacity electrode materials or battery systems with high energy density, high power density, and long cycling life.

sections.heading: 5.2. Unique Characteristic of NWs for LIBs
sections.text: Previous results have confirmed that the electrochemical performance of LIBs largely depends on the nanostructure of electrode materials, and reduction of particle size is one of the effective ways to release mechanical strains within particles and reduces lithium-ion diffusion length, thus improving the battery capacity retention and cycling life.10 Compared with the bulk materials, the NW electrode has several features for applications in LIBs including: (1) NWs with diameter in the nanometer scale allow for better accommodation of the volume changes for electrodes during lithiation/delithiation, avoiding structural fracture that usually occurs in bulk or micron-sized materials; (2) NWs provide a large surface area for electrode−electrolyte contact, increasing the active material utilization and reducing the charge−discharge time; (3) NWs effectively shorten the electron transport pathway and ion diffusion distance, enhancing the capacity and rate capability; (4) NW networks provide large aspect ratio and robust mechanical properties, making it suitable for buildingmultifunctional, 3D free-standing, and metallic current collector-free electrodes. In this section, we mainly focus on the discussion and overview of recent progress of NWs for advanced LIBs, covering anodes, cathodes, separators/solid-state electrolytes, and flexible electrodes.

sections.heading: 5.3. NWs as Anodes in LIBs
sections.text:
5.3.1. Lithium Storage in Si/Ge NWs. Continuous concerns over the energy and cost have prompted research into other new electrode materials with high capacity and low cost for LIBs. Si is one of the most promising materials for nextgeneration anodes since it possesses high theoretical capacity of 4200 mAh g−1, which is 10 times higher than that of commercial graphite.12,154−156 Other advantages of Si include being the second most abundant element on earth and that the lithiation potential is comparable to graphite (between 0 and 0.4 V vs Li/ Li+).14,156,157 However, Si is a semiconductor with low electronic conductivity and endures significant volume expansion (>300%) upon lithium insertion/extraction inducing unstable SEI layers and fast capacity fading during charge/ discharge, which hampered the practical application of Si electrodes.158 Nanostructured Si electrodes have been broadly investigated and well designed to address the above issues, such as 1D Si NWs,12,159 Si nanotubes,154,160 hollow Si spheres,161 yolk−shell structures,162 etc. Among these nanostructures, Si NWs have attracted great attention and represent a unique candidate of anode materials for practical applications in LIBs due to the following reasons:156,163 (1) Si NWs can provide rapid electronic and ionic transport pathways; (2) Si NWs with small diameters can accommodate large volume variation; (3) void space constructed by adjacent NWs allows for fast penetration and storage of electrolyte; and (4) Si NWs can offer high material utilization due to a high surface-to-volume ratio. Vapor−liquid−solid (VLS) CVD is one of the most commonly used methods to prepare Si NWs.12,13,164 Chan et al. adopted CVD-grown Si NW electrodes to accommodate large strain produced during lithium-ion insertion and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
Q
extraction, maintain good electronic contact with the current collector, and shorten the lithium-ion diffusion distance (Figure 17a).12 The Si NW anode delivered a first charging capacity of 4277 mAh g−1 and maintained a discharge capacity close to 75% of the maximum value during subsequent cycling, which are much higher than in the forms of Si film and particles (Figure 17b). Series structural characterization indicates that the Si NWs remained intact and did not break into smaller particles despite the large volume change that occurred during cycling, which contributes to the greatly improved capacity and cyclic stability. Further investigations reveal the structural transformations of Si NWs from crystal to an amorphous LixSi compound,
165 and Li2CO3 is an important component of SEI film
166 during lithium alloying reaction. Although quite good electrochemical performance was achieved, the Si NWmass loading is not high enough to satisfy practical applications. To increase the mass loading of Si NW electrodes, Hu et al. designed a 3D porous Si nanostructure by depositing Si nanoparticles from an aqueous Si ink with subsequent CVD coating of a thin-layer Si.167 Compared to the pure Si NW anode, this effective network structure increased the areal capacity by four times from 0.6 to 2.5 mAh cm−2. In another way, Li and co-workers reported Au nanoparticledecorated CNT hybrids to enhance the VLS growth of Si NWs on stainless steel with a high areal loading density.168 Compared to the Si NWs directly grown on Au-film-coated stainless steel,
the Si NW CNT nanostructures provide higher reversible capacity and increased areal capacity. To reduce the inactive weight of the current collector and improve the overall gravimetric capacities of the battery, the Au-deposited metal current collector-free, lightweight carbon nanofiber (CNF) film was used to grow Si NWs with greatly increased mass loadings and specific capacity.169,170 Furthermore, Peng and coauthors reported large-area, wafer-scale Si NW arrays as anode materials for LIBs by metal-induced chemical etching.171 The electrolessetched Si NWs have good conductivity and rough surfaces, which facilitate charge transport and insertion/extraction of Li ions. Longer cycling stability and higher capacity were achieved compared to the conventional planar-polished Si wafer. Other effective ways such as metal-assisted chemical etching of metallurgical Si,172,173 tin-seeded NWs by the supercritical fluid−liquid−solid (SFLS) method,174 and direct electrochemical reduction of CaSiO3
175 can produce large quantities of Si NWs and significantly increase the battery performance as well, which open up the routes for practical applications of Si NWs in existing industrial processes. Core−shell nanostructured Si NWs possess many desirable
properties in addressing the above challenges and improving the electrochemical performance. For instance, Cui et al. designed the direct growth of Si crystalline−amorphous core−shell NWs on stainless steel (SS) current collectors for high capacity and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
R
long-life LIBs (Figure 17c).159 It was recognized that amorphous Si shows superior cycling performance compared to crystalline Si because the homogeneous Li insertion has less volume expansion and pulverization, and the lithiation potential of the amorphous Si shell is higher than the crystalline Si core. Therefore, this design allows the lithiation of the amorphous Si shell while keeping crystalline Si NW cores stable to transport electrons. Through controlling the cutoff voltage at 150 mV, the core−shell NW electrode retains a capacity of 860 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with high Coulombic efficiency of around 99% at 0.8C (Figure 17d). The good electrochemical performance is confirmed by the post-mortem TEM characterization which shows that the crystalline Si core is maintained when limiting discharging potential above 150 mV but becomes amorphous when reacting with lithium at 10 mV (Figure 17e,f).159 The authors further extend the concept to construct CNF coreamorphous Si shell NWs by CVD coating of amorphous Si onto CNFs.176 The CNFs function as mechanical support and
electron-conducting pathways and endure less volume change compared to the crystalline Si core when discharging down to 10 mV because carbon has a much smaller capacity. Thus, a large charge capacity of ∼2000 mAh g−1 at 0.2C, a high area capacity of ∼4 mAh cm−2 at C/15, and good cycling life are achieved. Similar structures, such as TiC/C/Si core−shell NWs,177 crystalline core/amorphous shell Si NWs,178 Si-coated vertically aligned CNTs,179 Si-void@SiOxNWs,
180 and Si NWs/graphene core−shell electrodes181 also showed additional advantages in enhancing the electrical conductivity, structural stability, and electrochemical performance. Due to the poor conductivity, large volume change, and
unstable SEI formation on the surface of Si electrodes, attempts have been executed by coating or wrapping a conducting material on its surface. Carbon is one of the most promising coating materials due to its excellent electrical conductivity and superior chemical and electrochemical stability, which can greatly increase the rate performance and cycling lifetime of the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
S
electrodes. Kim et al. reported mesoporous Si@carbon NWs by impregnating a butyl-capped Si precursor into the SBA-15 template and annealing at 900 °C under vacuum (Figure 17g,h).182 When used as anode materials for LIBs, they demonstrate excellent first charge capacity of 3163 mAh g−1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 86% at a rate of 0.2C and keep a high rate capacity of 2462 mAh g−1 at 2C that was 78% of the capacity at 0.2C (Figure 17i).182 In another work, carbon-coated Si NW array films were fabricated bymetal catalytic etching of Si wafers followed by pyrolyzing of a carbon aerogel.183 Compared to the pristine Si NWs with fast capacity decay to 1144 mAh g−1 after 10 cycles, the carbon-coated Si NWs exhibit a high first discharge capacity of 3344 mAh g−1 and retain a reversible capacity of 1326 mAh g−1 after 40 cycles.183 From the practical point for applications of Si NWs in LIBs, scalable synthesis of Si NWs with low cost is necessary. To this end, a SFLSmethod was used to grow Si NWs at large scale with subsequent coating of carbon by pyrolysis of sugar.184 When employed as LIB anodes, the carbon-coated Si NWs mixed with multiwalled CNT retained a reversible capacity of 1500 mAh g−1 after 30 cycles, much better than the Si nanocrystals. Similarly, much better performance was achieved by Bogart and coauthors using the SFLS method with phenylsilane and bis(bis(trimethylsilyl)amino)tin as reactants to produce Si NWs with a conductive carbon skin.185 These excellent results are attributed to the uniform carbon coatings with improved electrical contact and conductivity, reduced aggregation, stabilized SEI, and buffered space for volume changes during lithium-ion insertion/ extraction. Other conducting coating materials, such as poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) polymers,186 copper,187 aluminum,188 tin,189 TiN,190 etc., have also been applied to improve the capacity, Coulombic efficiency, and cycling properties of Si NWs. Overall, these works discussed above demonstrate great potential for applications of Si NW-based anode materials in advanced LIBs.
To figure out the excellent performance of Si NW electrodes, considerable effort has been dedicated to the fundamental understanding of the lithiation in Si NWs. For example, to reveal the failure mechanism of Si anodes and unveil the metastable LiSi phases during lithiation, Misra et al. developed an X-ray transparent “pouch-type” cell (Figure 18a) to operate in situ synchrotron XRD on Si NWs during charging/discharging processes.191 The irreversible amorphization of Si NWs upon Li insertion is observed, and themetastable Li15Si4 phase that forms at deep lithiation voltage was confirmed. The formation of this metastable phase can be avoided by increasing the growth temperature (from 485 to 500 °C, Figure 18b) of the Si NWs since their crystallinity decreases at higher temperature.191 Based on the synthetic temperature control, the phase evolution of the Si NWs during lithiation/delithiation can be regulated with improved cycling stability. Therefore, an in situ XRD tool can provide a real time analysis of the crystal structure and valuable insight for better material design of Si anodes. In another work, the fundamental interaction between Li and Si atoms in the Si NW and themicroscopic dynamic process during Li insertion are revealed by first-principle calculations, in which the Li binding energy increases as the diameter grows and the [110] Si NWs demonstrate the highest Li binding energies on various insertion locations.192 Besides, the effects of porosity and pore size on the structure stability were simulated through considering the strain induced by lithium-ion intercalation and diffusion in boron-doped porous Si NWs (Figure 18c,d).193 The results reveal that a large pore size and high porosity help stabilize the structure while having low stress (Figure 18e), which is beneficial for getting high capacity and long cycle life. In addition, ex situ TEM was used to reveal the impacts of Si NW size and surface oxide on volume expansion; NWs with oxides show diameter-dependent volume expansion for which smaller NWs expand to a lesser degree than larger NWs, while oxide-free NWs expand to an approximately constant volume ratio for all
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
T
the sizes (Figure 18f). The other point indicated by this work is that the surface oxide can suppress the volume change during lithiation for NWs with diameters less than 50 nm, which is summarized by schematics in Figure 18g,h for illustrating the dimensional changes in Si NWs with different diameters.194 These understandings could help design optimized nanostructures for achieving excellent battery performance. Pairing the high-capacity Si NW anode with a lithium sulfide (Li2S) cathode or a prelithiated Si NW anode with a sulfur cathode is a promising approach to achieve high energy density batteries while at the same time avoiding the safety issues caused by the lithium dendrite problems.195−197 For instance, Yang et al. proposed a Li2S/mesoporous carbon composite cathode matched with a Si NW anode for a lithium metal free battery (Figure 19a).195 The incorporation of Li2S with CMK-3 mesoporous carbon and Si NW helps overcome the issues associated with sulfur cathodes and Si anodes in batteries, such as the dissolution of lithium polysulfide, low electrical conductivity of sulfur/Li2S and Si, large volume expansion of Si and sulfur, etc. This Li2S/Si full battery system delivers an initial discharge capacity of 423 mAh g−1 and maintained 250 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles at C/3, realizing an initial discharge
specific energy of 630 Wh kg−1 based on the mass of the active electrode materials (Figure 19b,c).195 From the aspect of consideration to pair all the Li-free cathodes, Liu et al. reported a facile prelithiation of Si NWs based on a self-discharge mechanism, in which Si NWs began to be electrochemically lithiated when pressure was applied to induce electrical shorting between the Si NWs and the Li foil (Figure 19d).196 After 20 min of prelithiation, ∼2000 mAh g−1 of lithium was preloaded into the Si NWs, and the nanostructure of Si NWs was maintained. By pairing this prelithiated Si NW anode with a S/ CMK-3 cathode, a proof-of-concept sulfur/Li-Si full cell exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 1060 mAh g−1 at 0.2C and maintained 60% of the initial capacity after 20 cycles (Figure 19e,f).196 In another case, Krause et al. adopted the electrochemical lithiation method to the first prelithiated Si NW/C composite electrode in the cell and then disassembled, rinsed, and reassembled them as an anode to pair with the sulfur/carbon composite cathode.198 The full cell shows a high areal capacity of 2.4 mAh cm−2 with capacity retention of 80% after 150 cycles (capacity loss lower than 0.4% per cycle) and good cycling life with a large specific capacity of 1.6 mAh cm−2 (714 mAh g−1sulfur) after 200 cycles. These prelithiation
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
U
methods, no matter at anodes or cathodes, open up new opportunities to pair high capacity counter electrodes for constructing the next generation of safe and high-energy density rechargeable batteries. Germanium (Ge) is another promising anode material in the same group as Si but has faster Li diffusivity (400 times) and higher electrical conductivity (104 times) than Si.199,200 Ge anode materials can store 4.4 Li+ per atom (Li4.4Ge) with a capacity of 1600 mAh g−1, which also significantly increases the energy density of LIBs.83 However, it also faces the issue of large volume change during lithium insertion/extraction, resulting in cracking of electrode materials and fast capacity fading. A nanostructured design can help to minimize the pulverization of a Ge anode, but maintaining a good electrical contact between the Ge active materials and current collector during cycling was another challenge. Building a direct contact between Ge NWs and the current collector is an efficient way to maintain the good electrical contact and integrity of the electrode. Chan et al. first reported the direct growth of Ge NWs onto metal current collector substrates through a VLS mechanism by CVD, and they were employed as high-capacity Li battery anodes.83 The electrode design ensures good electrical contact between the current collector and each individual NW, effectively accommodating the large strain during charge/ discharge processes and facilitating the ion transfer and electrolyte access, thus realizing a stable cycling life with reversible capacities of 1141 mAh g−1 at the C/20 rate and high rate of 2C with capacity of about 600 mAh g−1 and Coulombic efficiency larger than 99%.83 Ko et al. demonstrated the direct growth of high-density amorphous germanium suboxide (GeOx) layer sheathed Ge NW core/shell heterostructures on metal current collectors, which effectively relax the mechanical strain induced by volume changes and facilitate electron transport, thereby providing a large capacity of 900 mAh g−1 at 1C rate with little fading during cycles.201 Ionic liquid electrodeposition and a subsequent annealing strategy202 or wetchemical process with an evaporated Sn seed layer203 was also applied to grow Ge NWs on the current collector, which can be directly used as anodes in LIBs without the binder, resulting in the greatly improved electrochemical performance. Carbon materials with large surface area, high electrical conductivity, good chemical stability, and rich surface chemistry204−206 have attracted great interest as supporters, coating layers, and additives in Ge-based anodes for LIBs.200,207−209 For example, a single to a few layers of graphene was directly grown on presynthesized individual Ge NWs (Gr/ Ge NW) by a metal-catalyst-free CVD method.200 The coated graphene is of high quality that is comparable to the metalcatalyzed growth of graphene. By virtue of the tight encapsulation of graphene, the Gr/Ge NW electrode exhibits a high specific capacity of 1059 mAh g−1 at 4.0C and a long cycle life with capacity retention of 90% for more than 200 cycles, much better than that of bare Ge NWs with fast capacity fading in a few charging/discharging cycles. In another study, Choi and coworkers developed a redox-responsive reaction method by using a self-catalytic growth process (acetylene oxidation with GeO2 reduction) to assemble carbon-sheathed Ge NWs (C-Ge NWs) with hierarchical structure (Figure 20a).210 Ge NWs are grown via chemical reduction reactions involving GeO2 particles and subsequent self-catalytic growth, and carbon layers are uniformly coated on the surface of Ge NWs simultaneously (Figure 20b). The C-Ge NW electrodes demonstrated high rate capabilities with capacity retention of 40% at 5C rate compared
to the 0.2C rate, while bare Ge NWs failed at the same test conditions (Figure 20c). This simple but general redoxresponsive assembly opens up an effective way to fabricate carbon-coated Ge NWs with high performance. However, similar to the case of Si NWs, the current CVD growth method has limited yield and restricts its large-scale availability for practicable applications in LIBs. Electrospinning and low-energetic zincothermic reduction reaction were combined to large-scale synthesis of nanoporous Ge NWs with moderate porosity (Figure 20d).211 The nanoporous design facilitates the electrolyte penetration, shortens Li-ion transport pathways, and effectively accommodates volume expansion during repeated lithiation/delithiation that can be confirmed by the in situ TEM observation of lithiation/ delithiation processes (Figure 20e). As a result, the nanoporous Ge NW electrodes deliver a high initial reversible capacity of 1373mAh g−1, good capacity retention (80%) after 500 cycles at 3.0C, and high rate capability even at 30C that is much better compared to bare Ge NWs without porous structures (Figure 20f).211 Large quantities of Ge NWs fabricated via a solution− liquid−solid (SLS) mechanism212,213 or by an electrochemical liquid−liquid−solid process214, etc. have been employed as anodes for LIBs with improved reversible capacity, rate capability, and cycling capacity retention. To combine the advantages of high capacity, low cost Si, and high conductivity as well as fast Li-ion diffusivity of Ge anodes, axial Si−Ge heterostructuredNWs,215 Si−Ge (or Ge−Si) core− shell heterostructured NWs,216 Ge stem and Si branch heterostructured NWs,217 and alloyed Si1−xGex NWs 218,219 have been broadly investigated with tunable battery performance. Generally, a higher Si to Ge ratio enables a higher capacity, while a higher Ge to Si ratio allows for faster rate capability. For instance, Kennedy et al. rationally designed a binder-free Si−Ge heterostructure anode material composed of Si NW branches growing from Ge stems,217 in which the Ge NWs were directly grown from stainless steel current collectors by a vapor−solid− solid (VSS) mechanism, and the Si branches were then grafted to the Ge NW via the Sn seed catalysis growth (Figure 20g). Through adjusting the Ge to Si mass ratios, the Si-rich Si−Ge heterostructured anodes can deliver high capacity of ∼1800 mAh g−1 at 0.1C or exhibit high rate capacity of∼800mAh g−1 at 10C when Ge content dominates (Figure 20h). The unique nanostructure allows the Si−Ge heterostructured electrodes to be tailored for high-energy or high-power applications. In the latest work, they proposed another strategy to fabricate alloyed Si1−xGex NWs with different Si/Ge atomic ratios to harness the advantages of both high-capacity Si and high-rate Ge electrodes, thus realizing the tunable capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability.218 These rationally designed NWs with featured nanostructure and compositions, through changing the ratios and growth of Si and Ge, provide the opportunity to tune the performance of battery with high capacity or high power rate.
5.3.2. Lithium Storage in Metal Oxide NWs. Metal oxides, such as SnO2, Fe2O3, Fe3O4,MnO2, Co3O4, andNiO, are well-known electrode materials that can react with Li through a conversion mechanism, which contribute to high specific capacity and have been intensively investigated as potential alternatives to graphite anodes.205,220−222 Most of the metal oxides are also safe, environmentally benign, and low cost. However, the same issues such as poor electrical conductivity, easy agglomeration, slow ion transport kinetics, and large volume expansion/contraction during Li insertion/extraction lead to poor cycling stability and rate performance, hindering
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
V
their practical application as anode materials for LIBs.223−225 In order to address these issues, various NW-based structure designs have been adopted to improve the conductivity, shorten the ion transport length, relax the stress/strain, and finally boost the electrochemical performance of metal oxide NWs, such as hollow/porous NW structure, core−shell (coaxial) NW structure, coated NW structure, branched/hierarchical NW structure, NW arrays, and so on,226−228 which will be, respectively, discussed below. One of the prevailing solutions to address the issues of metal
oxide anodes is to construct the hollow or porous structures to accommodate large volume change and relieve the stress/strain, thus avoiding the rapid capacity fading, especially at high charging/discharging rates. Hollow and porous structures also facilitate ion diffusion and reaction kinetics of the electrodes. For example, a hierarchical hollow tubular structure composed of carbon-coated ultrathin SnO2 nanoplates (SnO2@C-HTs) was proposed for advanced anode material (Figure 21a,b).229 The obtained SnO2@C-HTs combine the advantages of 1D hollow tubular structure, ultrathin nanoplates, and carbon coating, manifesting high specific capacity and rate capability (Figure 21c). Other than hollow structure design, Li et al. reported the growth of mesoporous Co3O4 NW arrays on Ti foil by a mild template-free method, which can be directly used as anode materials for LIBs.230 The NW array electrodes can retain 85% capacity at 8C and 50% at even 50C relative to the capacity (∼700 mAh g−1) at 1C, much better than the broken Co3O4
NWs or powders. The high capacity and good rate capability are ascribed to the unique mesoporous NW array architecture, which improves the electron/ion transport, ensures enough electrolyte/electrode contact area, and relaxes the stress caused by the volume change during the electrochemical conversion processes. Similarly, this strategy was extended to grow porous Co3O4 nanoneedle arrays on a low cost copper foil substrate with fast charging/discharging and high reversible capacity.231
Hu et al. investigated the influence of templates (soft template, hard template, and soft−hard dual-template approaches) on the structural and electrochemical properties of ordered mesoporous carbon/Fe2O3 NW composite electrodes and revealed the synergetic effects of the dual-template strategy integrating the advantages of both soft and hard single-template methods, resulting in the optimized mesoporous size, volume, and Fe2O3 loading and thus the best electrochemical performance (Figure 21d−f).232 Other examples such as porous SnO2 NW bundles,233 mesoporous orthorhombic MoO3 NW bundles, 234 mesoporous Co3O4 NWs, 235 and porous ZnCo2O4 NWs 236 show significantly improved capacity and cycling performance due to the porous NW structures with large surface area and alleviated volume variation. Direct growth of NW arrays on conductive current collectors
represents an attractive nanostructure to overcome the issues existing in metal oxide anodes due to the following reasons: (1) each individual NW contacts closely with the substrate, ensuring good electron transfer and sufficient electrochemical reaction;
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
W
(2) no binders or extra conductive additives are needed, increasing the energy density of the whole electrode; (3) sufficient space among neighboring NWs can accommodate the volume change and allow for quick diffusion of ions and storage of the electrolytes, enabling fast charging/discharging capability and good structural stability. Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) or TiO2 is regarded as an ideal anode material for LIBs because it is a zero-strain insertion material with flat discharge and charge plateaus, which also avoids the formation of SEI and lithium deposition.237−241 However, the low electronic conductivity of the LTO and TiO2 electrodes restricts their applications in high power density batteries and corresponding devices. Shen et al. designed a template-free route to fabricate LTO NW arrays on Ti foil through directly growing H2Ti2O5·H2O NW arrays followed by chemical lithiation in LiOH solution.242 A hydrogenation annealing treatment is utilized to create Ti3+ sites to improve the electronic
conductivity of LTO NWs (H-LTO NWs). The self-supported H-LTO NW arrays can be used as anodes for LIBs without binders and conductive carbon black, manifesting a capacity of 120 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 30C (5.3 A g−1) that is 3 times greater than pure LTO NW arrays. Moreover, the H-LTO NW arrays exhibit much better cyclic stability, maintaining a capacity of 149 mAh g−1 at 5C after 100 cycles, than pristine LTO NW arrays with a value of only 107 mAh g−1 tested at the same conditions. The excellent rate capability and significantly enhanced cycling performance are due to the well-aligned NW electrodes with large specific space facilitating the lithium-ion transfer, the improved electronic conductivity by introducing Ti3+ states, and the direct connection of H-LTO NW arrays to the growth substrate with fast electrochemical reaction. However, the issues facing LTO or TiO2 are that the capacity is only half compared to graphite, and the higher charging/ discharging plateaus in fact lead to lower energy density because
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
X
of the reduced cell voltage output. Therefore, LTO- or TiO2based anodes need to couple with high-voltage cathodes to achieve a relatively high output cell voltage and thus a suitable energy density.243
To further increase the specific capacity, metal oxides involved with more electron conversion reactions, such as Co3O4 244 and Ni3V2O8 245 NW arrays grown on Ti foil, SnO2 NW arrays grown on stainless steel246 or graphite,247 and CuO248 and Fe2O3@Co3O4
249 NW arrays grown on nickel foam,manifest greatly improved electrochemical performance in terms of capacity, rate capability, and cycling life. By virtue of lightweight substrates such as carbon cloths, carbon papers, and other carbon-based films, the NW arrays can be directly grown on their surface as electrodes for high-performance LIBs.250−255 For instance, mesoporous NiCo2O4 NW arrays were grown on carbon textile substrates through a surfactant-assisted hydrothermal method followed by an annealing treatment and applied as freestanding anodes (Figure 21g,h).250 Each NiCo2O4 NW directly contacts with the carbon fiber and ensures a good electrical connection, and the mesoporous structure allows for fast ion transfer and alleviates the volume change, exhibiting a reversible capacity of 1012 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and 854 mAh
g−1 after 100 cycles with 84% capacity retention, superior to the NiCo2O4 microsphere electrode with only 400 mAh g
−1 tested at the same conditions (Figure 21i). Core−shell (coaxial) NW structures possess many unique properties to enhance the electrochemical performance of metal oxide anodes, e.g., preventing the core materials from agglomeration, reducing the side reactions by shell protection, alleviating volume change, and retaining the stable structure of the electrodes. A thermal evaporation process was applied to fabricate SnO2−In2O3 core−shell NWs, which can improve the electrical conductivity by 2 orders of magnitude compared to the pure SnO2 NWs due to the formation of the Sn-doped In2O3 shell nanostructure.256 Based on this heterostructure, the SnO2−In2O3 core−shell NW electrodes deliver 60% higher reversible capacity than that of the pure SnO2 NWs. Benefiting from the small diameter, high aspect ratio, and the flexible characteristics, CNTs can realize an efficient electric contact with active materials and form a high conducting network. MnO2-coated CNT coaxial nanotube arrays were prepared by vacuum infiltration and CVD techniques using porous alumina templates.257 The CNT core provides improved electrical conductivity, acts as a buffer to accommodate the volume
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
Y
expansion, and contributes additional sites for lithium storage, achieving a reversible capacity an order higher compared to pure MnO2 nanotubes. For another case, Liao et al. designed a TiO2− C/MnO2 core−shell NW array on a Ti current collector via a layer-by-layer deposition process, which integrates the benefits of the excellent stability of TiO2, good electrical conductivity of the graphitic carbon layer, and high capacity of MnO2 (Figure 22a,b).26 The unique structural features endow the TiO2−C/ MnO2 core−shell NW anodes self-supported, additive free capability with excellent electrochemical performance for LIBs including a high capacity of 865 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and excellent rate performance of 130 mAh g−1 at 30C (1C = 335 mA g−1), much better compared to that of the TiO2 and TiO2-C NWs (Figure 22c).26 Other works reported the employment of Co3O4/C, 258 Co3O4/NiO/C, 259 ZnCo2O4/NiO,
260 core/shell NW arrays grown on nickel foam, coaxial Zn2GeO4@carbon, 261 Fe3O4/CuO 262 NWs grown on Cu foils, ZnCo2O4 NWs grown on Ni foam core/shell structure,263 etc. as binders and conductive-free electrodes for long-life and highly efficient LIBs. The other promising strategy to conquer the shortcomings of metal oxide anodes is to incorporate carbonaceous materials or highly conducting metals as a coating layer or encapsulation supporter, which not only builds an efficient electron/ion transport network but also offers buffer space for volume change, thus greatly improving the rate capability and capacity retention of the electrodes.204,206,264−266 A hollow Fe2O3 nanosphere uniformly dispersed in the carbon matrix bubble-nanorod structure was synthesized by two-step heat treatment of electrospun precursor nanofibers under H2/Ar and air atmospheres (Figure 22d,e).267 The Fe2O3-carbon bubblenanorod composite retains a high capacity of 812 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 1 A g−1, much higher than the hollow bare Fe2O3 nanofibers with only 285 mAh g−1 capacity (Figure 22f). Even when the current density increases to 5.0 A g−1, a stable reversible capacity of 491 mAh g−1 can be reached and the discharge capacity recovered when the current density was restored to a small value of 0.5 A g−1 (Figure 22g).267 This significantly improved structural stability and electrochemical performance are attributed to the hollow sphere structure that accommodates the mechanical stress, the unique NW morphology, and the carbon protection that inhibit the aggregation of Fe2O3 into larger particles. Graphene is efficient in constructing a conductive network in the composites with 2D plane structure, in which both sides can be accessed by ions and electrolytes, and has raised considerable interest as conductive and flexible substrates for supporting or encapsulating metal oxides.268 1Dmesoporous Co3O4NWswere incorporated into a 3D nitrogen-doped graphene aerogel (NGA-Co3O4) through one-pot hydrothermal reaction followed by topotactic calcination (Figure 22h,i).269 When used as the anode material, a capacity of 1229 mAh g−1 was retained over 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1, which was three and four times higher in comparison with sole nitrogen-doped graphene aerogel or mesoporous Co3O4 NWs, respectively (Figure 22j).
269 The highlight of this work is the unique integration of nitrogen doping, a flexible 3D graphene scaffold, and a 1D mesoporous NW, enabling high electrical conductivity, good electrode/electrolyte wettability, accelerated ion transport, and large interfacial area and active sites for lithiation/delithaiton with enhanced electrochemical kinetics. Surface carbonmodification of metal oxide electrodes is essential to effectively accelerate charge and mass transfer and provides an elastic buffer layer to prevent the active materials from pulverization and aggregation. Therefore, when used as
anode materials in LIBs, carbon-decorated single-crystalline Fe3O4 NWs, 270 MoO2/Mo2C/carbon hybrid NWs, 271 and graphene-reinforced MnO NWs272 exhibit significantly improved reversible capacity, rate performance, and cycling life. The hierarchical/branched NW structure is another representative approach to alleviate the self-aggregated effect of metal oxides during cycling and enhance the contact areas of active materials with electrolytes.21,221 Constructing hierarchical/ branched NW structure can also provide adequate room to accommodate the stress caused by the volume change and integrate the full advantages of the synergistic promotion of each electrode material. To this end, Zhou et al. combined a vapor transport deposition and hydrothermal method to design a 6- fold symmetry-branched heterostructure composed of a SnO2 NW stem and α-Fe2O3 nanorod branches (Figure 23a).
273 The novel branched nano-heterostructured electrode delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 1167 mAh g−1 and 69.4% capacity retention after 30 cycles (Figure 23b), which was higher than the single component of SnO2 NWs (612 mAh g
−1, 43.6% capacity retention) or α-Fe2O3 nanorods (598 mAh g
−1, 56.1% capacity retention). The improved performance is attributed to the synergetic effect between SnO2 and α-Fe2O3 and the unique branched nanostructures that enable more accessed surface areas and released stress/strain during cycling. 3D Co3O4/CuO NW heterostructure arrays were developed with hierarchical arrangement of CuONW stems and Co3O4 nanosheet branches on nickel foam via electron beam evaporation, thermal oxidation, chemical bath deposition, and the calcination process (Figure 23c).274 Branched Co3O4 nanosheet branches with high porosity and density are uniformly grown on the surface of CuO NWs (Figure 23d,e). As binder- and conductive-free anodes for LIBs, a high reversible capacity of 1191 mAh g−1 was obtained with 90.9% capacity retention after 200 cycles at 200 mA g−1 (Figure 23f), which is substantially higher than that of single Co3O4 nanosheets with capacity of 664 mAh g
−1 after 100 cycles and CuO NWs with only 554 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles.274 Followed by this work, a versatile method was proposed to produce hierarchical porous 3D transition metal oxide core/ shell arrays with tubular heterostructures on copper foam, which was composed of CuO nanotubes as the backbone and various branched nanostructured metal oxides (including CoO, NiCo2O4, ZnCo2O4, and CuxCo3−xO4).
275 The hierarchical/ branched NW structure has also been broadly built by other materials to boost the battery performance such as hierarchical porous Fe3O4/graphene NWs supported by amorphous vanadium oxide matrixes,276 branched Co3O4/Fe2O3 NW heterostructure,277 SnO2 NWs assembled on MnO2 nanosheets,278 hierarchical mesoporous TiO2 NW bundle superstructures,279 hierarchical core−shell CoO@SiO2 NW clusters,280 and so forth. The superior electrochemical performance of these hierarchical NW arrays compared to the single counterpart electrode can be ascribed to the large interfacial area for fast lithium insertion/extraction, short diffusion distance, alleviated volume change, and excellent conductive network for electrons and ions, whichmaximize the utilization of electrochemically active materials. Currently, the commercially available anode materials are mainly based on graphite or other carbonaceous materials due to their cheap cost, low working voltage, and stable cyclic life. However, the limited theoretical capacity and rate capability of carbon materials promote the development of alternative anode materials with large capacities and good rate performance. As discussed in this section, the key issue for achieving high
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
Z
performance LIBs is to enable multielectron conversion with high capacity, efficient electron/ion transport with high power capability, and stable structure features with long cycle life. From these understandings, high-performance Si, Ge, and transitional metal oxide NW-based anodes were designed based on the use
of conductive material coating, hollow/porous design, 3D NW arrays, core−shell (coaxial) NW structure, and hierarchical structure. Table 2 summarized the electrochemical performance of representative NW-based anode materials in LIBs. Although these NW-based electrodes exhibit several times higher the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AA
lithium storage capacity compared to graphite, most types of NWs have not been used in real batteries. One notable example is the Si NWanode, which has been used in batteries for practical applications. For Ge NW electrodes, the lithiation of crystalline Ge is a complex process since many parameters such as the lithium-ion diffusion direction, amorphous−crystalline transformations, and the reaction rates/fracture behavior differ at different orientations. As for metal oxide anodes, a more important but often overlooked obstacle for their application is the staggering voltage hysteresis observed between discharge and charge, which severely diminishes the efficiency of the electrode. Therefore, although metal oxide NW based structure design provides important information on material properties, it does not lead to practical electrode materials in LIBs. A better understanding of the origin of voltage hysteresis may offer an opportunity to dramatically lower the energy barrier and improve the energy efficiency. Despite the existing challenges, rational design and development of advanced NW-based anode materials will open up more new research opportunities for improving energy storage performance.

sections.heading: 5.4. NWs as Cathodes in LIBs (LiCoO2, LiFePO4, LiMn2O4, Vanadium Oxide NWs, etc.)
sections.text:
Layered LiCoO2 is the current broadly used commercial cathode material in LIBs, which has a theoretical capacity of 274mAh g−1
if all the Li is extracted, while only half of the capacity (about 140 mAh g−1) is reversible based on the intercalation reaction.152
Whenmore than 0.7 Li is extracted, the crystal structure stability will be destroyed, and cobalt dissolution is serious, resulting in fast capacity decay.285 1D NW electrode design offers the possibilities to further enhance the electrochemical performance of the LiCoO2 electrode due to the better accommodated stress/ strain, large surface-to-volume ratio, and fast Li-ion transport pathways. Jiao et al. fabricated a LiCoO2 NW and mesoporous LiCoO2NW through a hard template route to formmesoporous or NW Co3O4 and then reacts with a lithium source of LiOH (Figure 24a,b).286Mesoporous LiCoO2NWexhibits the highest capacity and cycling stability compared with the LiCoO2 NW and normal LiCoO2 particles between the potential range of 3.0−4.2 V (Figure 24c), suggesting the merits of NW structure mentioned above. Xiao and co-workers reported a two-step approach to obtain (010) plane exposed LiCoO2 NWs by hydrothermal synthesis of Co(CO3)0.35Cl0.2(OH)1.1 followed by calcination.287 LiCoO2 NW electrode retained 80% of the initial capacity when current density increases from 100 to 1000 mA g−1, and the capacity retention was higher than 80% at 1000 mA g−1 after 100 cycles. The high rate performance and cycle stability can be ascribed to the 1D transport of electrons along the NW direction and the exposure of the electrochemically active (010) plane facilitating fast Li+ intercalation/deintercalation. 3D mesoporous structure or chain-like LiCoO2 NW arrays were also fabricated on metal substrates by a two-step hydrothermal method with or without calcination and applied as cathode materials for 3D microbatteries.288 The chain-like LiCoO2 NW arrays exhibit larger gravimetric capacity and areal capacity, higher rate capability, and improved cycling stability compared to those of 2D planar LiCoO2 thin films and Al nanorod-supported LiCoO2 arrays, which can be ascribed to the 3D electrode architecture with high surface area and stable NW structure with fast Li-ion transport and high reversibility on repeated Li insertion and extraction. Despite the wide application of LiCoO2 in the battery market, its high cost,
toxicity, and limited abundance of cobalt drive the exploration of alternative cathodes. Spinel LiMn2O4 is one of the prospective cathode candidates with low cost, nontoxicity, abundance, and suitable capacity of 148mAh g−1.289 However, the phase transition from the cubic to tetragonal phase due to the deep discharge and the sluggish lithium-ion diffusion kinetics causes the capacity fading and poor rate capability of LiMn2O4 electrodes.
290 To address these issues, Kim and coauthors demonstrate the combination of hydrothermal and solid-state sintering reactions to synthesize single-crystalline LiMn2O4 nanorods, which deliver a high capacity of 100 mAh g−1 at a current density of 148 mA g−1 that is two times larger capacity compared with commercially available LiMn2O4 powders.
291 Meanwhile, more than 85% of the initial capacity is maintained after 100 cycles, which is due to a small change of lattice parameter when Li ions intercalated into the cubic phase of the 1D LiMn2O4 nanorod, followed by the coexistence of two identical cubic phases in the potential range of 3.5−4.3 V.291 Generally, high-temperature sintering is required to obtain good performance with high crystallinity of LiMn2O4. To avoid the issues of large grain size, aggregation, and related poor battery performance during this calcination process, Hosono et al. reported a high-quality single-crystal LiMn2O4 NW synthesized using the Na0.44MnO2 NW as a self-sacrificing template, which helps alleviate the aggregation and grain growth at high temperature.292 The single-crystal LiMn2O4 NW electrodes demonstrate a flat charge−discharge potential plateau and excellent rate capacities of 108 and 88 mAh g−1 at 5 and 20 A g−1, respectively. Different from the template method to prevent coarsening of the grains, Lee et al. designed ultrathin spinel LiMn2O4 NWs employing a solvothermal reaction to prepare α-MnO2 NWs followed by solid-state reaction at low temperature (480 °C) with LiOH under low pressure (Figure 24d,e).293 The obtained ultrathin, single-crystalline LiMn2O4 NWs with diameter of 10 nm and length of several micrometers (Figure 24e) greatly enhance the kinetics of the electrode, which displayed capacities of 116 and 90 mAh g−1 at 1 and 20C between 3.1 and 4.3 V, respectively (Figure 24f). The fast kinetic properties are ascribed to the high crystallinity, fast lithium diffusion path along the 1D NW, and the favorable structural transformation of the cubic and tetragonal phase without structural distortion. Based on the LiMn2O4 NW cathodes, single nanorod devices for battery diagnostics were demonstrated by Yang et al.,294 and later Wang et al. further assembled an all-nanowire-based flexible Li-ion full cell with Mn2O3 NW anodes, which shows good cycling capability with a reversible capacity of ∼80 mAh g−1 and Coulombic efficiency of >95% after 40 cycles.295
Polyanion-based positive electrodes, such as LiFePO4, LiMnPO4, and Li3V2(PO4)3 (LVP), are other prospective cathode materials because of their large theoretical specific capacity, high voltage plateau, and stable structure.152,285,296 Nevertheless, the intrinsic low electrical conductivity and sluggish ion transport have limited the active material utilization and rate capability of the electrodes, impeding their practical applications. The hard template method was employed to synthesize LiFePO4 NW cathodes to enhance the material utilization with >85% capacity retention of the initial capacity at a high rate of 15C.297 However, the template removal requires the use of NaOH, which could possibly react with LiFePO4 to destroy the structure.298 To avoid the use of etching solution, a triaxial carbon-coated LiFePO4@multiwall CNT core NW
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AB
structure299 or carbon-coated single-crystalline LiFePO4 NWs (SCNW-LFP) with thin diameters around 100 nm300 was produced by an electrospinning approach, which creates an efficient conductive network with short diffusion lengths and significantly improved cycling stability and rate capability (Figure 25a, b). CNT-encapsulated LiFePO4 NW-conducting networks were reported by solid-state reaction, in which the LiFePO4 NWs reduce the diffusion path of Li ions, while CNT coating ensures a fast electron conduction path and protects electrodes from direct contact with the electrolyte, thus achieving a high capacity of 160 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and excellent rate performance of 65 mAh g−1 at 50C.301 Similar results were demonstrated by the other works using carbon-coated LiMnPO4 nanorods302 or carbon-encapsulated LiFe1−yMnyPO4 nanofiber303 to improve the charge storage capacities and power rates of the composite electrodes. To improve the electron and ion transport, Wei et al. discovered a new principle of synergistically improving structure stability and electrical transport property of electrode materials
through the unique structural interface design of hierarchical NWs.34 Hierarchical Li3V2(PO4)3/C mesoporous NWs were synthesized via hydrothermal and annealing treatment. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide and oxalic acid were used as surfactants and carbon sources to form the mesoporous carbon scaffolds with bicontinuous electron/ion pathways (Figure 25c,d). The Li3V2(PO4)3/C mesoporous NW cathode exhibits high rate and long-life performance with capacity retention of 80.0% after 3000 cycles at 5C between 3 and 4.3 V, much better compared with the carbon-coated Li3V2(PO4)3 particles and pure LVP particles (Figure 25e),34 which can be attributed to the hierarchical bicontinuous electron/ion pathways, large electrode−electrolyte contact area, and excellent structure stability on prolonged cycling. Later, Niu et al. further designed a gradient electrospinning and controlled pyrolysis method to synthesize 1D carbon-coated Li3V2(PO4)3 mesoporous nanotubes, in which small Li3V2(PO4)3 nanoparticles distributed on the ultrathin CNT walls.31 Due to the large electrode− electrolyte contact area, reduced charge transfer resistance,
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AC
and abundant mesoporous structure for fast ion/electron transport and stress release, Li3V2(PO4)3 mesoporous nanotube electrodes exhibit stable cycling for 9500 cycles with a capacity retention of 80% at 10C. Moreover, the Li3V2(PO4)3/Li4Ti5O12 full cell delivers a capacity of 74 mAh g−1 at 5 C and recovers 96% of the initial capacity when the rate is returned to 2C, demonstrating an excellent rate performance.31
In addition, LiV3O8 has been extensively studied as a promising cathode candidate due to its high specific capacity, good structural stability, and low cost.285,304 A facile route has been proposed to fabricate ultralong LiV3O8 NWs by topotactic lithiation of H2V3O8 NWs (Figure 25f,g), which showed a high discharge capacity of 176 mAh g−1 at the current density of 1500 mA g−1 and can be maintained at 160 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles with 0.025% capacity fading per cycle.304 The LiV3O8 NW cathode also exhibited a long life for 600 cycles at a current density of 2000 mA g−1 with an even lower capacity fading of only 0.022% per cycle (Figure 25h).304 The optimized calcination temperature helps producea suitable degree of crystallinity and high surface area, enabling low charge transfer resistance and good structural stability, contributing to the excellent electrochemical performance. Afterward, Ren et al. developed a hierarchical LiV3O8 nanowire-in-network structure via a controlled electrospinning strategy through cross-linking poly(vinyl alcohol) and poly(ethylene oxide).305 The obtained LiV3O8 cathode exhibits a high initial capacity of 320.6 mAh g −1 at 100 mA g−1 and a high rate capacity of 202.8 mAh g−1 at 2000 mA g−1, which is ascribed to hierarchical NW structure with a large contact area between LiV3O8 and electrolytes, low charge transfer resistance, and improved structural stability.305 The demonstrated cross-linking strategy in the electrospinning
method could be extended to construct other architectures for advanced electrode materials. Vanadium oxides are another alternative candidate based on
the conversion reaction as high-energy cathodes for LIBs due to their large specific capacity, low cost, easy synthesis, and abundant resources.152,306 Despite these advantages, vanadium oxides have suffered from their low electronic conductivity, poor structural stability, agglomeration during cycling, and slow reaction kinetics, resulting in low rate capability and limited long-term cycling stability. In order to overcome these drawbacks, Lee and coauthors designed a V2O5 NW−graphene composite paper in which ultrathin V2O5 NWs (10 nm) were uniformly dispersed between the graphene sheets.307 The composite electrodes exhibit excellent rate capabilities with a capacity of 255.5 mAh g−1 at 10 A g−1 in the case of 15 wt % of V2O5, equaling to 1.5 min of charging/discharging time. More importantly, a capacity of 94.4 mAh g−1 remained after cycling 100 000 cycles at high current density of 10 A g−1, implying the robust structure.307 The fascinating properties can be attributed to the small dimensions of V2O5 NWs with reduced lithium-ion diffusion lengths and the intimate contacts between V2O5 NWs and graphene improving electron transport and restricting the structural variation. Yan et al. discovered a new electron/ion bicontinuous-transport effect regulating electrochemical reaction kinetics. An ultralong semihollow graphene scroll selfcoated on the V3O7 NWs through an oriented assembly approach was designed.308 The V3O7 NW templated graphene scrolls (VGSs) show a length over 30 μm with interior cavities that allow for free volume expansion of V3O7, provide ion transfer channels, and restrain self-aggregation of V3O7 during cycling. Different from other reported metal oxide/graphene
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AD
mixtures, all the individual V3O7 NWs were encapsulated by the self-scrolled graphene (Figure 26a). Molecular dynamic simulations reveal that the graphene sheet starts to wrap the V3O7 NW due to their interaction energy, and after the formation of a first-layer graphene scroll, the wrapping process proceeded spontaneously due to amore stable state after coating (Figure 26b). Therefore, the VGS electrodes deliver a high specific capacity of 321 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and 87.3% capacity retention after 400 cycles at 2000 mA g−1, much better compared to pure V3O7 NWs and the graphene−V3O7 NW mixture (Figure 26c).308 A freestanding graphene−V2O5 NW composite paper cathode was also designed for high-temperature (80 °C) all-solid-state LIBs with high safety and energy density.309 Coating conductive polymers are another way to improve the electrical conductivity of V2O5 NWs. Inspired by the cucumber-like structure, MnO2 NP enriched V2O5/PEDOT heterostructured coaxial NWs were designed with high cycling stability at low rate, which is due to the enhanced electrical and ionic conductivity by PEDOT and MnO2 modification.
24 The conducting materials demonstrated in the above examples not only improve the electrical conductivities of vanadium oxide electrodes but also help prevent them from agglomeration during cycling. As a result, significantly promoted battery performance was reached. Assembling the NWs into a functional architecture will endow the materials with new properties. Mai et al. adopted a convenient and versatile electrospinning and annealing method to prepare ultralong hierarchical vanadium oxide NWs composed of attached single-crystalline vanadium oxide nanorods (Figure 26d,e).310 The NWs have a diameter of 100−200 nm and length up to several millimeters which prevents selfaggregation and keeps the effective contact areas of active materials exposed to electrolytes. Therefore, this novel hierarchical nanostructured vanadium oxide NW cathode exhibits a high discharge capacity of 275 mAh g−1 when cycling between 2.0 and 4.0 V and improved cycling stability (Figure 26f), much higher than self-aggregated short nanorods with a discharge capacity of 110−130 mAh g−1.310 After that, a 3D NW/nanorod interconnected V2O5 nanowork was constructed with high surface area and large pore volume, which exhibited excellent capacity retention of 96.4% and 98.8% after 1000
cycles at 1.0 and 2.0 A g−1.311 The good battery performance due to the interconnected NW networks enables continuous electron/ion transport among the subunits, provides enough free space to store electrolytes, and buffers the volume change during repeated lithiation/delithiation processes. To prevent self-aggregation and pulverization, other 3D nanostructures, such as hollow VO2 NWmicrospheres,
25 intertwined VO2 NW/ CNT composites,312 and carbon quantum dot decorated VO2interlaced NWs grown on 3D carbon cloth,313 etc. have been fabricated and demonstrated greatly improved electrical conductivities and structural stability. For example, hollow microspheres assembled by VO2 NWs were fabricated through a controllable ion-modulating strategy,25 which allows free expansion and shrinking on both radial and axial directions, increases the surface area and active sites, and inhibits the selfaggregation of NWs during lithium intercalation/deintercalation, thus enabling a high capacity and excellent cyclability. Similar improvements were also reported on various kinds of
other active cathode materials including β-AgVO3 NW clusters314 or AgVO3/polyaniline (PANI) triaxial NWs,
315 FeS or FeS2@carbon NWs,
284,316,317 and Cu2S NW arrays grown on copper substrates,318 etc. Table 3 summarizes the electrochemical performance of representative NW-based cathode materials in LIBs. The above discussions suggest that the assembly of the NWs into functional architectures or integration of NW electrodes with conducting materials such as graphene, CNTs, or polymers can effectively address the issues of cathode materials that suffer from low ionic and electronic conductivities, slow reaction kinetics, and poor structural stability. However, it should be noted that even though the NW-based electrodes exhibit improved capacity and cycling life there should be a balance between the addition amounts of conducting materials and active material loading to maintain high specific energy density and at the same time good electrical conductivity. Moreover, the NW-assembled hollow or hierarchical architectures for cathode materials inevitably reduce the packing density or volumetric energy density of the whole electrodes, which is another challenge limiting their practical applications and still an open question for further investigation and improvement.

sections.heading: 5.5. NW-Based Separators/Solid-State Electrolytes in LIBs
sections.text:
Up to now, most of the efforts have been concentrated on designing NW-based cathode or anode materials, and the separator, as another critical component to ensure the safety of the batteries, has received less attention. The discussion in this section will be focused on the progress of the separator based on NWs. Generally, development of high-energy and safe lithium batteries also relies on exploiting advanced separators. The basic function of the separator is to provide electrical insulation between the cathode and the anode to prevent an internal short circuit while serving as an electrolyte reservoir and enabling free ionic transport.319,320 The other requirement for the separator is to have good wetting ability and thermal stability.321 However, the commercially available polyolefin-based microporous separators, such as polyethylene and polypropylene, suffer from poor thermal stability, low porosity, and inferior electrolyte wettability, which greatly affect the electrochemical performance of LIBs.320
In order to address these issues, Li et al. designed a flexible and porous separator based on hydroxyapatite (HAP) NW networks and cellulose fibers (CFs) with good electrolyte wettability, thermal stability, and fire resistance.322 HAP NWs and CFs are self-assembled via the hydrogen bonding and van der Waals force to form a hierarchical cross-linked network structure
(Figure 27a,b). The highly flexible, robust, and porous HAP NW/CF separator was obtained after filtration and drying (Figure 27c), which demonstrates excellent electrolyte wettability with near zero contact angle and thermal stability up to as high as 700 °C. In particular, the integrated separator exhibits much better cyclability and rate capability compared to the commercial polypropylene separator, suggesting that it is promising as a separator for advanced LIBs with high safety (Figure 27d).322
Electrospun assembly of NW-based separator is another promising route to enable a high liquid electrolyte uptake and rich porosity due to its large surface area and interconnected pore structure. Electrospinning of thermal-resistant polymer membranes, such as polyimides (PI), has been extensively applied to enhance the thermal stability and mechanical properties of separators for safety batteries.323−325 For example, PANI NWs were in situ polymerized on the electrospun PI nanofibers to form a 3D hierarchical architectured composite (PANI/PI) separator with good mechanical properties.325 The PI nanofiber constructs an interconnected, open porous structure which facilitates the flow of electrolyte and the transportation of a lithium ion. The thin coating layer of PANI NWs on the surface of the PI nanofiber can further improve the electrolyte wettability and ion affinity of the separator. The
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AF
thermal stability and ionic conductivity have also been improved compared with the traditional polyolefin separators. As a result, the PANI/PI composite separator exhibits higher capacity, cycling stability, and rate capability compared to the pure PI nanofiber and polyolefin separators. In another study, Liu et al. designed a safe nonwoven core−shell microfiber separator with thermal-triggered flame-retardant properties for LIBs through electrospinning.326 The microfiber core is composed of an organophosphorus-based flame retardant (triphenyl phosphate (TPP)), and poly(vinylidene fluoride)-hexafluoropropylene (PVDF-HFP) is set for the shell due to its relatively low melting point (∼160 °C) that can be melted at the early stage of combustion (Figure 27e). The PVDF-HFP shell can effectively prevent the dissolution of TPP during the normal running of the battery, while when the thermal runway happens inside the battery, the PVDF-HFP polymer shell would melt and release the flame retardant, which could effectively suppress the combustion of the highly flammable electrolytes and improve the safety of batteries (Figure 27f).326
The above progress shows the promises of NW-based separators for safer rechargeable Li-ion batteries. Despite that the ionic conductivity, thermal stability, electrolyte uptake, and wetting properties of separators have been improved, the employment of liquid electrolytes to infiltrate the separator is still necessary, which poses a great safety concern due to the easy flammability of organic solvents. In this respect, replacing the liquid electrolytes with solid-state ionic conductors is thus promising due to the solvent-free characteristics, good electro-
chemical stability, and nonflammability properties, which can significantly improve the safety of LIBs. The solid-state electrolyte functions as the medium to transport ions, which can be generally divided into two categories: inorganic electrolytes and solid polymer electrolytes.327 Inorganic solidstate electrolytes have relative high ionic conductivity at room temperature; however, the poor mechanical strength and large interfacial resistance hinder their practical application.328 Compared to inorganic solid materials, polymer-based solid electrolytes with good flexibility and low cost are promising; nevertheless, enhancing the ionic conductivity within suitable working temperature range is one of the key challenges. Dispersing secondary-phase fillers to hinder the polymer crystallization or create conductive interface layers between polymer and fillers can drastically improve the ionic conductivity of polymer electrolytes.329 For instance, TiO2, 330 Al2O3, 330,331 and SiO2 332 nanoparticles have been added into the PEO to inhibit crystallization and boost ionic conductivity of the composites. Compared to nanoparticle fillers with many particle−particle junctions for Li ion to pass through, 1D NW fillers with high aspect ratio can greatly reduce junction resistance due to the continuous ionic transport pathways along the NWs. In addition, NWs have the advantages over nanoparticles in overcoming the aggregation contributing to a higher ionic conductivity. Liu et al. proposed to disperse electrospun Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (LLTO) NWs into a polyacrylonitrile (PAN)-LiClO4 polymer without other additives to fabricate a composite polymer
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AG
electrolyte (Figure 28a).333 The LLTO NWs with high aspect ratio provide 3D Li-ion-conducting pathways in the polymer matrix, which is significantly different from the isolated distributed nanoparticles (Figure 28a). LLTO itself is also a good lithium-ion conductor that can participate in Li-ion transport. Therefore, the NW-based composite polymer electrolyte with 15 wt % filling offers 3 orders of magnitude improvement in ionic conductivity (2.4 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature) compared to pure solid polymer electrolyte without fillers and is 2 orders of magnitude higher than the LLTO nanoparticle fillers. Following this work, other NW-filled solid-state electrolytes such as Mg2B2O5 and palygorskite NWs also exhibit improved ionic conductivity, mechanical properties, working voltage range, and safety.334,335
Further demonstration by Liu and co-workers indicates that compared with the randomly dispersed NWs solid composite polymer electrolytes with well-aligned Li-ion conducting LLTO NWs along the normal direction of electrodes exhibit 1 order of magnitude enhancement in ionic conductivity compared to the randomNWcounterpart (Figure 28b,c), which is ascribed to the fast ion-conducting pathway without crossing junctions on the surfaces of the aligned NWs.336 Zhang et al. also demonstrated the engineering of continuous ceramic−polymer interfaces through filling polymer electrolyte into the vertically aligned nanochannels of anodized aluminum oxide (AAO) for realizing fast Li-ion transport pathways and excellent stability.337 The NW fillers combined with the aligned nanoarchitecture design provide a new avenue for developing high ionic conductivity solid electrolytes. Another type of extensively used ceramic filler is garnet-type Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) solid electrolyte with high ionic conductivity and wide voltage stability window.338,339 Similarly, LLZO NW filler-based solid electrolytes with different phases, size, and crystal structure prepared by an electrospinning strategy have been investigated, which demonstrated improved ionic conductivity and mechanical strength compared to the LLZO particle filler.340−343 For instance, to prevent the agglomeration of LLZO fillers and maintain a long-range ion transport, Fu et al. developed a 3D lithium-ion-conducting network composed of LLZO nanofibers in PEO polymer electrolytes.342 LLZO nanofibers were fabricated by electrospinning of PVP polymer and a LLZO salt mixture followed by high-temperature annealing in air. This 3D membrane electrolyte not only provides good mechanical properties to block dendrite penetration but also exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 2.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature, demonstrating great potential for application in Li-based high capacity energy storage systems. To examine the performance of this kind of composite electrolytes in all-solid-state batteries, an integrated structure was employed by using PEO as a binder in the cathode and dispersing LLZO NWs into PEO polymer/lithium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide as electrolytes (PLLN).343 The PEO in the cathode and electrolytes can fuse together at suitable temperature to strengthen the interface and maintain fast ion transportation with low resistance during cycling. LLZO NWs inside reduce the activation energy and increase the ionic conductivity as well as mechanical strength, enabling good electrochemical performance in all-solid-state LiFePO4/PLLN/ Li batteries. Besides restraining polymer crystallization, Lewis acid−base interactions between the filler surface and electrolyte anions is another effective strategy to set free Li ions and thus increase ionic conductivity of solid polymer electrolytes.329,344 This
mechanism is considered, as the rich Lewis acid sites on the filler surfaces interact with salt anions to release the positively charged Li ions. Based on the knowledge from solid oxide fuel cells that Y2O3-doped ZrO2 (YSZ) can produce high concentration of oxygen vacancies (Lewis acid sites) in ZrO2 with a positively charged surface, Liu et al. effectively improved the ionic conductivity by dispersing optimized contents of YSZ NWs into the PAN-LiClO4 polymer electrolytes (Figure 28d).
345 By tuning the concentration of vacancies in YSZ NWs, combined with the continuous ion-conducting pathways offered by the 3D NW structure, a maximum concentration of dissociative Li ions can be realized with the highest conductivity. Compared with conventional liquid organic electrolyte with the issues of flammability, leakage, and poor chemical stability, solid-state electrolytes possess greatly improved electrochemical stability and safety. However, the low ionic conductivity of solidstate electrolytes, especially at low temperatures, requests further exploration. Optimization of the electrode/electrolyte interface to reduce the interfacial contact resistance is necessary to enable good adhesion and high utilization of the electrode materials. Solid polymer electrolytes take advantages of high ionic conductive inorganic fillers, and flexible polymer electrolytes have intriguing prospects; however, the detailed mechanisms of ion transport and interaction at the filler−polymer interface for the greatly improved conductivity in the composite electrolyte are still not fully understood, which requires further investigation on the fundamental studies.

sections.heading: 5.6. Advantages of NW Electrodes for Flexible LIBs
sections.text:
Flexible batteries have attracted considerable attention recently because of their potential applications as power sources for flexible electronics such as roll-up displays, artificial skins, touch screens, sensors, implantable medical devices, and so on.346−349 However, the most commonly used electrode materials containing particles are usually rigid and hard to cater to the requirements of flexible electrodes. NWs with high aspect ratio, superior electrical properties, fast charge transfer, and outstanding mechanical flexibility offer great opportunities for building flexible electrodes in the area of energy storage. Nam and co-workers demonstrated the synthesis and assembly of Co3O4 NWs with a conductive Au coating to form a Au−Co3O4 NW hybrid as a high-performance anode for LIBs.350 Au NPs on the surface not only improve the electrical conductivity of Co3O4 NWs but also catalyze the reaction of Li with Co3O4, enabling a higher reversible lithium storage capacity compared to the pure Co3O4 NWs. When assembling Co3O4 NWs onto a transparent and free-standing poly(ethylenimine)/ poly(acrylic acid) film, a thin and flexible LIB can be constructed, which exhibits a high rate capability with 94% of its theoretical capacity at 1.12C and 65% at 5.19C.350 Vald et al. proposed an approach for recycling electronic wastes of Si chips by the metal-assisted chemical etching approach, which allows for large-scale NW synthesis and precise tuning of the NW morphology.351 By impregnating the Si NW arrays with a polymer matrix, a polymer-embedded Si NW composite can be peeled off from the substrate, which is a flexible and mechanically robust gel−electrolyte membrane. An electroless coating of a thin Cu layer is developed to wrap on the Si NWs with improved electric conductivity, capacity retention, and rate capabilities as compared to the pristine NWs.When the Si NW− polymer composite anode is matched with the LiCoO2 cathode, a 3.4 V battery is demonstrated, delivering an initial capacity of 155 mAh g−1 at a current rate of C/20.351
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AH
Different from the aforementionedmethods that impregnated polymer into the NWs to construct flexible electrode, a nonwoven Si fabric with good mechanical integrity and flexibility was directly prepared by casting concentrated dispersions of crystalline Si NWs (Figure 29a).352 Polyphenylsilane coating on the Si fabric followed by annealing in a reducing environment enabled the formation of an electrically conductive carbon layer on the surface. This fabric was composed of highly entangled Si NWs (range in diameter from 10 to 50 nm with a thickness of ∼50 μm) with 90% void volume, which can be applied as self-supporting anode material for LIBs without adding the conductive carbon or binders (Figure 29b). The space between the NWs favors ion transport and accommodates Si volume expansion during the repeated cycling processes. After annealing the NW fabric at different temperature, the fabric turns increasingly black with enhanced electrical conductivity (Figure 29c). The electrochemical test indicates the optimized condition is annealing the fabric at 900 °C under reducing atmosphere, which leads to excellent performance with a capacity of more than 800 mAh g−1 at C/ 20 (Figure 29d). Similarly, a flexible membrane consisting of an ultralong MnO/C coaxial NW was fabricated for advanced anode materials.353 Ultralong MnO2 NWs were first synthesized by a hydrothermal method and assembled into a freestanding membrane. The carbon-coated MnO coaxial NW membranes were then obtained by in situ interfacial polymerization of polypyrrole followed by a carbonization process. By virtue of the ultralong 1D nanostructure and the high conductive carbon
coating, the freestanding coaxial MnO/C anode delivers a high reversible capacity of 832 mAh g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles, good rate capability, and cycling stability with a specific capacity of 480 mAh g−1 after 600 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g−1.353 Recently, Luo et al. fabricated a free-standing Sb2Se3 NW-based membrane through a hydrothermal synthesis followed by vacuum filtration treatment.44 The obtained freestanding membrane exhibits good flexibility and integrity, which exhibits reversible capacities of 614 and 360 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1, when used as an anode for LIBs and sodium-ion batteries, respectively. Besides carbon coating on the active materials, Kawamori et al. proposed an integrated NW electrode composed of tangled conductive metallic NWs and coated active materials for LIBs (Figure 29e).354 This electrode design has the advantages of high surface area, sufficient space for fast ion/electron transport, and accommodating the large volume change during cycling processes, which also avoids the addition of binders, conductive additives, and current collectors, improving the energy density of batteries. NiO-coated nickel NW nonwoven cloth was demonstrated as a prototype flexible electrode for LIBs (Figure 29f and g), which exhibits good mechanical strength for twisting and tying (Figure 29h and i) and higher capacity and better cycle performance compared to the NiO nanoparticle-based electrodes. The assembly of a NW-based membrane electrode is promising for building flexible electrodes for LIBs due to their large aspect ratio and specific surface area. The direct
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AI
employment of the integrated membrane electrode eliminates the need of additional binders, conducting additives, and current collectors. However, most of the high-capacity electrodes such as Si, Sn, and metal oxides are semiconductors or insulators, which requires the conductive surface coating or modification of metal layers to improve their electrical conductivity. Development of flexible LIBs based on the advantages of NW electrodes is still an exciting and promising direction.

sections.heading: 5.7. Summary
sections.text: In this section, we discussed the advantages and challenges of NWs as anodes, cathodes, separators/solid-state electrolytes for LIBs and their unique characteristics for building flexible electrodes and devices.
