NW electrodes manifest several features for battery applications compared with their bulk materials, and significant progress has been made in this field. For example, the 1D geometry offers fast charge transfer along the NW direction, and the nanosized diameter allows for better stress/strain relaxation during lithiation/delithiation. The large aspect ratio of NWs provides more accessible active sites for electrochemical reactions, increasing the active material utilization. In addition, building secondary structures based on the NWs or growing NWs directly on conductive substrates provides the avenues to overcome the electron/charge transfer resistance, volume change, and self-aggregation problems. However, challenges and opportunities coexist for large-scale implementation of NW electrodes. The mass loading of NW electrodes is relatively low (usually lower than 2mg cm−2) with an areal capacity lower than 2mAh cm−2, still far away from the commercial LIBs with a value of 4 mAh cm−2.355 Feasible solutions for realizing high mass loading are still urgently required, and constructing 3D structured NW electrodes or employing lightweight CNT/ carbon nanofiber networks as current collectors can be alternative ways to increase active material loading or reduce the weight of traditional heavy metal foils, and thus increase the capacity of the whole electrode. The practical application of metal oxide NWs as anode materials is still challenging due to their high irreversible capacities and large voltage hysteresis. More theoretical understandings are required to address the drawbacks of metal oxide based anodes in large initial irreversible capacities. Moreover, no obvious voltage plateau leads to unstable full cell voltage output, which also limits their real use. Although the irreversible capacity at the first cycle for metal oxide anodes still exists, they can be good choices as cathode prelithiation agents to offset initial lithium loss.356 A stable SEI layer is necessary to guarantee the long-term cycling stability, especially for high surface area NW electrode materials. Electrolyte additives, such as vinylene carbonate (VC),357 for in situ formation of a stable artificial passivation layer on the NW electrode and precise design of surface structure or functional groups are promising approaches to stabilize the electrode surface. The volumetric energy density and packing density of the NW-based electrodes are expected to be decreased, compared to their bulk counterpart. However, assembling the NW building blocks into a hierarchical/branched heterostructure offers an efficient way to increase the volumetric energy density of the whole electrodes.

sections.heading: 6.1. Brief Introduction of SIBs, Facing Challenges, and Unique Characteristics of NWs for SIBs
sections.text:
Rechargeable batteries are of interest for high-energy storage in portable, electric vehicles and stationary applications. The
ambient temperature SIBs are considered as the potential candidates for meeting large-scale grid energy storage owing to the wide availability, low cost of sodium, and similar physicochemical property compared with lithium (Table 4).358−360 However, on account of the fact that the Na ion has
a larger ionic radius than the Li ion, the diffusion of the Na ion is intrinsically slower than that of the Li ion during charge/ discharge processes, resulting in lower reversible capacity and inferior rate capability.361 Thus, in order to achieve the continuous improvements of the power and energy densities of the sodium-ion storage devices, the key issues are the promotions in the performance of electrode materials and the design of suitable electrode nanoarchitectures.20 Among various nanostructures, 1D NW structures become promising candidates for the SIB electrodes owing to the advantages of easy electrolyte access to the active material, short ionic diffusion length, and the ability to accommodate volume changes during the electrochemical reaction process.

sections.heading: 6.2. NWs as Cathodes in SIBs
sections.text:
6.2.1. Sodium Storage in Layered Transition Metal Oxide NWs. Layered sodium transition metal oxides have attracted much attention among cathode materials for SIBs due to their high promise for practical applications. Some effort has been taken to improve the electrochemical performance of layered sodium transition metal oxides via constructing a 1D nanostructure. Kalluri et al.362 synthesized the P2-type Na2/3(Fe1/2Mn1/2)O2 hierarchical nanofibers via electrospinning technology and evaluated their electrochemical performance as cathode materials for SIBs. The average diameter of asprepared Na2/3(Fe1/2Mn1/2)O2 hierarchical nanofibers is about 170 nm (Figure 30a,b). At the current density of 26 mA g−1, the Na2/3(Fe1/2Mn1/2)O2 hierarchical nanofibers display an initial discharge capacity of about 195 mAh g−1 in the potential range of 1.5−4.2 V (Figure 30c). Moreover, the capacity of Na2/3(Fe1/2Mn1/2)O2 hierarchical nanofibers remains at 167 mAh g−1 after 80 cycles, which is much higher than that of Na2/3(Fe1/2Mn1/2)O2 nanoparticles. The superior sodium storage performance is ascribed to the hierarchical nanofiber structure which enhances the electronic and ionic conductivities (Figure 30d). In order to further improve the electrochemical performance of layered sodium transition metal oxides, carbonaceous materials have been introduced to optimize the electronic conductivity. Niu et al.31 obtained carbon-supported Na0.7Fe0.7Mn0.3O2 mesoporous nanotubes via a gradient electrospinning strategy. In the as-synthesized Na0.7Fe0.7Mn0.3O2 mesoporous nanotubes, the Na0.7Fe0.7Mn0.3O2 nanoparticles with size of about 10 nm are embedded in the ultrathin CNTs with diameter of about 100 nm (Figure 30e). Benefiting from this structure, Na0.7Fe0.7Mn0.3O2 mesoporous nanotubes exhibit superior sodium storage performance (Figure 30f). At 500 mA
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AJ
g−1, a discharge capacity of 82 mAh g−1 was obtained at first cycle in 3−4.5 V. Moreover, the capacity retention of 70% was still achieved even after 5000 cycles. In addition, some layered transition metal oxide NWs without
removable sodium ions, especially layered vanadium oxideNWs, also have been investigated as cathode materials for SIBs. Su et al.363 evaluated the sodium storage performance of bilayered V2O5 nanobelts. The obtained nanobelts are 90 nm in width (Figure 31a) and exhibit a capacity of as high as 235.7 mAh g−1 at low current density of 40 mA g−1 (Figure 31b). At a high current density of 640 mA g−1, the capacity of 134 mAh g−1 was still realized with good cycling stability in 100 cycles. Wei et al.364 employed iron preintercalation to improve the electrochemical performance of vanadium oxide nanobelts. The iron preintercalated vanadium oxide nanobelts were synthesized via a facile hydrothermal method (Figure 31c). Compared to vanadium oxide nanobelts, iron preintercalated vanadium oxide nanobelts deliver higher sodium storage capacity and enhanced cycling performance (Figure 31d). Besides, designing substructure based on NWs is also an efficient approach to improve the sodium storage performance of vanadium oxide NWs. Dong et al.365 reported the electrochemical performance of hierarchical zigzag Na1.25V3O8 NWs. The hierarchical zigzag NWs are composed of short nanorods with specific orientation (Figure 31e). Compared to general Na1.25V3O8 NWs, the hierarchical zigzag Na1.25V3O8 NWs display improved sodium storage capacity and rate performance (Figure 31f). Moreover, after 1000 cycles at 1000 mA g−1, the capacity retention of 87% was achieved. 6.2.2. SodiumStorage in Polyanionic CompoundNWs.
Due to its structural stability and chemical diversity, polyanionic compounds have received wide attention. The research for the polyanion electrodes has focused on iron-based,366−369 vanadium-based,370,371 and manganese-based372,373 polyanion compounds. Niu et al. reported graphene-wrapped Na6.24Fe4.88(P2O7)4 composite nanofibers (NFPO@C@rGO)
as SIB cathode materials.374 With the good contact between the NFPO@C and graphene, NFPO@C@rGO has a great electronic conductivity, fast ionic transport, and large reaction surface, resulting in a better cycling stability and rate performance than NFPO@C and pristine NFPO. As shown in Figure 32a, a capacity of ∼99 mAh g−1 can be achieved with a current density of 40 mA g−1 after 320 cycles. In particular, the NFPO@C@rGO has a capacity of∼53.9 mAh g−1 even at 1280 mA g−1 (11C) (Figure 32b). In order to improve the conductivity of polyanion compounds, novel NaVPO4F/C nanofibers are prepared via an electrospinning method and used as a cathode material in SIBs,375 and the morphology of the nanofibers is shown in Figure 32c,d. A high capacity of 126.3 mAh g−1 at 1C and a superior rate capability (61.2 mAh g−1 at 50C) were achieved in a half cell. It also delivered an ultralong cyclic stability (96.5% capacity retention) even after 1000 cycles at 2C, as displayed in Figure 32e. Na3V2(PO4)3/C nanofibers (CNFs), in which the Na3V2(PO4)3 nanoparticles were uniformly encapsulated by interconnecting CNFs (Figure 32f), were synthesized.376 As shown in Figure 32g, at 0.1C, an initial discharge capacity of 123 mAh g−1 (pure Na3V2(PO4)3) was obtained. Even at current density of 20C, the capacity can retain 24 mAh g−1 due to the CNFs having a high conductive network. Recently, Na3V2(PO4)3 NWs (Figure 32h) were also synthesized by Mai’s group with a novel gradient-electrospinning and controlled-pyrolysis methodology.31

sections.heading: 6.3. NWs as Anodes in SIBs
sections.text:
6.3.1. Carbonaceous Materials and Polyanionic Compounds. In recent years, more and more researchers are focusing on carbonaceous materials due to their large interlayer distance and unordered structure, which facilitate Na-ion insertion and extraction.377−380 It can be seen that carbonaceous materials in the form of NWs will be more conducive to play to their respective advantages. For example, the sodium storage performance of hollow carbon NWs (HCNWs) prepared through pyrolization of the polyaniline precursor was studied
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AK
by Cao et al. (Figure 33a−e).381 When serving as an anode for SIBs, this material demonstrated superior electrochemical performance. At a current density of 500 mA g−1 (2C), a high reversible capacity of 149 mAh g−1 could be obtained (Figure 33g). It also delivered a capacity retention of 82.2% after 400 cycles at a current density of 50 mA g−1 (Figure 33f), showing outstanding cycling stability. The authors attributed this excellent electrochemical performance to the following two points: (1) the hollow structure endows this material a high specific surface, which provides much more active sites as well as contact area between the electrode and electrolyte, and (2) the large interlayer spacing (0.37 nm, Figure 33d) between the graphitic sheets, leading to effective insertion and transfer of Na ions during the charge−discharge process. A kind of graphene NWwas also synthesized by Liu et al. via a template strategy.283 Due to the unique physical and chemical properties of grapheneNWs, the new graphene-based electrodes
showed excellent electrochemical performance when applied as the anode for Na-ion batteries. This electrode delivered a high reversible capacity of more than 200 mAh g−1 at 20C and stabilized at 297 mAh g−1 without fading even after 1000 cycles, demonstrating ultrahigh rate capability and long-term cycling stability. Polyanionic compounds, described as NaxMyNz (among them, M represents metallic elements, such as Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Ti, V, etc., and N represents (PO4) 3−, (SO4) 4−, (SiO4)
4−, etc.), have more robust crystal structures and show relatively higher Na+ conductivity.382 As a typical example of polyanionic compounds, Na3V2(PO4)3 has received extensive attention in both anodes and cathodes for SIBs owing to its large interstitial spaces for quick diffusion of the Na ion and multiple valence states of the V element. The Na3V2(PO4)3/C composite can display more remarkable rate performance when applied in SIBs. Zhu et al.383 successfully prepared Na3V2(PO4)3/C composite
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AL
nanofibers via coaxial electrospinning followed by calcination. When applied as an anode for SIBs, the Na3V2(PO4)3/C nanofibers demonstrate a high reversible capacity of 189.9 mAh g−1 at a current density of 23.6mA g−1 during 0.01−3 V (vsNa+/ Na). This anode still displays 105.1 and 80.4 mAh g−1 at the second cycle even at high rates of 590 and 1180 mA g−1. Meanwhile, capacity retention is 83 and 77% after 200 and 500 cycles, respectively, showing outstanding Na+ storage performance. 6.3.2. Metals and Metal Oxides. NW structure has been widely used to explore the electrochemical mechanism and performance of metal and metal oxide anode materials for SIBs. In the past decade, NWs of metal and metal oxide anode materials include TiO2,
384 CuO,385 ZnO,107 Ge,132 and SnO2,
127 etc. Gu et al. employed a state-of-the-art in situ TEM electrochemical testing technique to directly observe the structural and chemical evolution of SnO2 NWs upon sodiation/desodiation.127 In their work, Na metal was attached to a tungsten rod, which was loaded on the holder. On the other end, the SnO2 NWs were welded onto a gold rod by conductive epoxy as shown in Figure 34a. As shown in Figure 34b,c,
microstructural evolution of the SnO2 NW upon Na insertion (first sodiation) is presented. The NW swells with the progression of sodiation, which is also clearly illustrated by the isolated single NW at the right side of the image. This NW grows from 67 to 145 nm in diameter following full sodiation as marked in the figures. In Figure 34d, the formation of pores (indicated by the red arrows) and the shrinkage of the NW (that NW shrinks to 109 nm in diameter after Na extraction) after extraction of Na upon desodiation are illustrated. As schematically illustrated in Figure 34e, upon Na+ insertion into SnO2, a displacement reaction occurs: (4 + x) Na+ + (4 + x) e− + SnO2 → NaxSn (amorphous) + 2 Na2O, leading to the formation of amorphous NaxSn particles, which are dispersed in the Na2O matrix. The amorphous NaxSn transforms to crystalline Na15Sn4 when x reaches the critical value of 3.75. The morphology and spatial correlation of NaxSn depend on multiple factors, such as the defect density of the SnO2 NW, the shape of the SnO2, and the reaction kinetics. Xu et al. also employed in situ TEM to visualize themicrostructural evolution and phase transformation and to track ion diffusion during electrochemical sodiation of ZnO NWs (ZNWs).107 For single-crystalline ZNWs (sc-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AM
ZNWs), a slow and step-by-step sodiation process was observed. A reaction front propagates slowly along the sc-ZNWs, and heterogeneous interfaces are formed inside the ZNWs due to nonuniform sodiation amorphization during sodiation. Crystal-
line NaZn13 nanograins dispersed in the Na2O matrix could be formed with Na inserted into ZnO, and a displacement reaction occurred. A step-by-step electrochemical sodiation behavior for the sc-ZNWs is revealed.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AN
6.3.3. Metal Sulfides. Nanostructured metal sulfides have drawn extensive attention as potential anodes for SIBs because of their quantum size effects, low price, low potential, and absence of safety risks.386,387 Mesoporous vine-like MoS2 nanofibers (NFs) were fabricated via a one-step electrospinning method. The diameter of each fiber is 100−200 nm, and the diameter of each bundle is about 500 nm (Figure 35a−c).388
The MoS2 NF electrode delivered a high discharge capacity of 840 mAh g−1 at the second cycle and showed excellent rate capability even at 5C compared to the bulk MoS2 electrode (Figure 35d−f). After coated by TiO2, the active material shows
decreased capacity due to the increase of its total mass. The enhanced performance is due to the exceptionally large surface area and numerous reaction sites with Na ions in the reduced fiber size. Liu et al. reported a new type of WS2 NW as an anode for SIBs.389 The NWs with a diameter of about 25 nm and expanded interlayer spacing of 0.83 nm offer good electrolyte access to active materials and open channels for rapid Na-ion diffusion. WS2 NWs display a superior cyclability (1400 cycles with considerable capacity of 330 mAh g−1 at 1000 mA g−1) due to that the intercalation mechanism only takes place and the conversion reaction is avoided by limiting the cutoff voltage to
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AO
0.5 V.389 In this case, the NW structure is well preserved, and the expanded WS2 layers offer more active sites for Na-ion storage, resulting in fast electronic and ionic diffusion kinetics. Other metal sulfides have also been widely investigated for sodium-ion storage, such as Sb2S3, 390 FeS2, 391 and so on.

sections.heading: 6.4. Summary
sections.text: To date, the electrochemical performance of SIBs still lags behind that of LIBs in terms of reversible capacity, high rate capability, and cycling performance. 1D NWs with the advantages of easy electrolyte access to the active material, short ionic diffusion length, and the ability to accommodate volume changes during the electrochemical reaction process could lead to improvements in SIB performance. Table 5 summarizes the electrochemical performance of several representative NW-based electrodes in SIBs. Remarkably, some key advances have been made in layered P2-type and carbonaceous materials, which means the further improvements of the energy and power density for sodium-ion storage could reach the requirements of practical application. Moreover, more systematacially experimental and theoretical studies are needed to optimize and investige the performance andmechanism of 1D NWs for sodium-ion storage. We believe that sodium-ion storage devices based on 1D NWs will be a promising direction in the future.

sections.heading: 7.1. Brief Introduction of Li-S Batteries and the Challenges to Overcome
sections.text:
With the ever-increasing desire for batteries with high-energy density and low cost, the current core of battery research is the exploration of new electrode materials or battery chemistries beyond the LIB technology to satisfy these goals. Li-S batteries are promising as alternative battery chemistries due to their high theoretical energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), which is 5-fold higher than the current commercial LIBs.11,392 The Li-S battery configuration is similar to that of LIBs, which is commonly comprised of a sulfur-based cathode bound to a metallic current collector using binders, a Li metal anode, and a separator incorporated with a liquid organic electrolyte.393,394 The electrode reaction based on sulfur chemistry is complicated because the solid−liquid−solid phase transitions are involved during the discharge/charge process with transformation as follows: S8 + 16 Li
+ + 16 e− ↔ 8 Li2S. This is a two-electron conversion reaction. During the discharge process, the sulfur is reduced in which S−S bonds are cleaved to open the S8 crown molecular, forming various polysulfides and combining with lithium ions to produce soluble lithium polysulfides (Li2Sx, 3≤ x ≤ 8) and ultimately form Li2S or Li2S2, while electrons flow through an external circuit (Figure 36a).395−397 These solid
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AP
sulfides are electrochemically decomposed to form lithium ions and polysulfides during the charging process.398,399 Besides the high theoretical capacity and energy, sulfur is also abundant and inexpensive, enabling the Li-S battery system to be commercially viable.400 Despite these promising advantages, the practical applications of Li-S batteries are still hindered by several challenges, including the electrical and ionic insulation of sulfur and discharge products Li2S2/Li2S, large volumetric change during the charge and discharge processes, and the polysulfide shuttling effect caused by the dissolved lithium polysulfides in the electrolytes, leading to low material utilization, serious structural damage for the electrode materials,401 fast capacity fading, and low Coulombic efficiency.402−404

sections.heading: 7.2. NW-Based Composite Cathodes in Li-S Batteries
sections.text:
So far, much effort has been devoted to the design of the nanostructured cathode for addressing the above issues and improving the energy density and cycle life of Li-S batteries.394,396,405 Various carbon materials have been utilized as hosts for constructing carbon−sulfur composites to accommodate sulfur inside pores, improve their conductivity,
restrict dissolution of sulfur, and suppress the shuttle effect in the Li-S battery.393−396,402 Ji et al. demonstrated that mesoporous carbon could store sulfur and exhibits strong capability in confining sulfur while providing a facile ion transport pathway.402 Besides mesoporous carbon, 1D nanostructured carbonbased sulfur cathodes have been broadly investigated for advanced Li-S batteries due to their high aspect ratios and excellent electronic conductivity.406,407 Significantly improved capacity and cycling stability were achieved by coating sulfur on single-walled408 and multiwalled CNTs409 and vertically aligned CNT arrays.410,411 However, sulfur dissolution and a mild polysulfide shuttle between the sulfur cathode and lithium anode are inevitable due to the residual sulfur outside the surface of CNTs. Zheng et al. designed a hollow CNF derived from AAO templates to encapsulate sulfur (Figure 36b).30 The AAO template is beneficial in facilitating sulfur infusion into the inner surface of hollow CNFs instead of the exterior surface. The hollow CNFs with a high aspect ratio effectively confine sulfur, reduce volumetric expansion, and restrict the diffusion of polysulfides, and the thin carbon wall allows fast transport of lithium ions, enabling a high initial capacity of around 1400mAh
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AQ
g−1 and retaining a reversible capacity of about 730 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles at a 0.2C rate.30 A similar disordered CNTsulfur nanostructure was realized by Guo et al. through dropping sulfur solution on the CNTs followed by high-temperature treatment.412 The heat treatment breaks down the S8 molecule to small S6 or S2 and forms S−C bonding, restricting the dissolution of polysulfide, which makes the sulfur cathode exhibit good stability with 72.9% capacity retention after 100 cycles.412 Different from the above strategies, Zhou et al. elaborately designed a S-CNT cathode by confining sulfur inside the wall of the CNT by AAO template-directed CVD of carbon and carbothermal reduction of sulfate (Figure 36c,d).406 This unique nanostructured cathode has the beneficial integration of a highly conductive CNT matrix, the strong confinement of elemental sulfur in CNT walls, and a mesoporous structure for fast ion migration. Therefore, this cathode exhibits a high
discharge capacity of 520 mAh g−1 (50 wt % S) at a high current density of 6 A g−1 based on the mass of sulfur.406
A large amount of work has reported improved Li-S battery performance by incorporating carbon materials with sulfur;395,413−415 however, Cui’s group first pointed out the weak interaction between nonpolar carbon materials and polar lithium polysulfide species.407 The weak binding causes lithium polysulfide/Li2S to detach from the carbon surface during the discharge process, which leads to fast capacity decay. This phenomenon is confirmed by ex-situ TEM study (Figure 36e,f).407 Combined with first-principles calculations, they demonstrated by modifying the carbon surface with amphiphilic PVP that the capacity fading can be alleviated as strong chemical interactions were introduced between the polar polymer and lithium polysulfides (Figure 36g,h). Themodified sulfur cathode exhibited a high specific capacity of 1180 mAh g−1 at C/5 and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AR
excellent capacity retention of 80% after 300 cycles at C/2.407 Therefore, only combining carbonaceous materials with sulfur is difficult to address the challenges existing in Li-S batteries, especially for the high sulfur content and loading conditions. Xiao et al. proposed to encapsulate sulfur via a soft approach using self-assembled PANI nanotubes (PANI-NT) as a matrix.416 After annealing treatment of the PANI nanotubes at 280 °C with sulfur, in situ vulcanization occurs in which a fraction of sulfur reacts with the PANI, forming a 3D, crosslinked, structurally stable S-PANI composite (Figure 37a,b).416 The PANI backbones are interconnected with inter- and/or intrachain disulfide bonds. This S-PANI polymer composite not only provides physical confinement but also strong chemical interaction to the elemental sulfur and lithium polysulfides, ensuring a good cyclic stability and rate capability. As a result, the S-PANI-NT composite cathode exhibited a discharge capacity of 837 mAh g−1 at 0.1C rate after 100 cycles and a long-term stability of 500 cycles at 1C with 76% capacity retention (Figure 37c). Other conductive polymers,397,417 such as polypyrrole NW-based networks, combined the functions of conductive additives, distribution, and adsorbing agents and applied them as a host for stabilized sulfur chemistry.417
Besides polymers, carbides, sulfides, oxides, and nitrides with good conductivity, strong chemical interaction, and superior catalytic effect are promising in Li-S batteries.398,418−420 For example, Luo et al. recently demonstrated a lightweight, freestanding substrate composed of boron-carbide (B4C) NWs grown on CNFs (B4C@CNF) for high performance Li-S batteries (Figure 37d,e).418 CNF acts as both a template and carbon source to react with boron powder under the help of nickel catalyst to grow B4C NWs. The B4C NWs not only provide chemical-anchoring centers to strongly adsorb polysulfides but also act as catalysts to accelerate the redox kinetics of polysulfide conversion. Based on this bifunctional cathode substrate, significantly improved performance with capacity retention of 80% after 500 cycles at 1C and high rate capacity of 304 mAh g−1 at 4C is accomplished. A high areal capacity of 9 mAh cm−2 with a high sulfur content (70 wt %) and sulfur loading (10.3 mg cm−2) is achieved. More intriguingly, the B4C@CNF substrate with a high sulfur mass of 200 mg can deliver a high discharge capacity of 125 mAh after 50 cycles in Li-S pouch cells (Figure 37f), indicating the great promise for practical application with high energy density. Another example demonstrated by Li et al. impregnated sulfur into microporous carbon-coated conductive mesoporous vanadium nitride NWs (S/MVN@CNWs) for high-performance Li-S batteries (Figure 37g).421 The sulfur particles are in the size of 2−5 nm and encapsulated by both mesoporous VN and microporous carbon. The sulfur and dissolved lithium polysulfides are physically trapped by the mesoporous VN and microporous carbon shell and chemically anchored by the mesoporous VN, effectively alleviating the diffusion of soluble polysulfides and ensuring good structure stability of the electrode. With an areal mass loading of 2.8 mg cm−2, the freestanding and binder-free S/ MVN@C NW cathode exhibits a high initial capacity of 1305 mAh g−1 at 0.2C and a high rate capacity of 543 mAh g−1 at 10C (Figure 37h).421 The physical and chemical combing strategy enables a large and stable capacity of 7.1 mAh cm−2 at a high areal mass loading of 9.7 mg cm−2, offering a feasible route to design high-energy Li-S batteries. Other NW-based configurations such as sulfur NW yarns,422 conductive porous VN nanoribbon/graphene composites,423 TiO2 NW arrays on CNFs,424 metal−organic framework-derived cobalt sulfide
NW arrays anchored onto a 3D graphene foam,425 and cobaltembedded nitrogen-doped hollow carbon nanorods426 also exhibit promising features as high-performance cathode substrates in Li-S batteries.

sections.heading: 7.3. NW Materials As Additives or Interlayers for Li-S Batteries
sections.text:
As discussed in the above section, metal oxides, sulfides, carbides, and nitrides have high surface area, large polysulfide adsorption capability, and strong catalytic effect on promoting the polysulfide redox reaction kinetics.398,427,428 In addition to the direct use as matrix materials, they are also found to be efficient when serving as additives for polysulfide absorbents or coating layers to suppress polysulfide shuttling in Li-S batteries. For example, Zhou et al. developed a free-standing TiO2 NWembedded graphene (TiO2 NW/G) hybrid membrane for Li/ polysulfide batteries, exploring the integration of physical and chemical adsorption materials to constrain a polysulfide shuttle.429 The graphene membrane was used as the current collector with high electrical conductivity, which can on one side reduce the contact resistance of the sulfur cathode and on the other side physically immobilize sulfur and the dissolved lithium polysulfides (Figure 38a). TiO2 NWs are brought into the graphene membrane to build up the hierarchical composite structure (Figure 38b), in which TiO2NWs not only have strong chemical binding with lithium polysulfides but also show a strong catalytic effect on polysulfide conversions. Therefore, after the introduction of TiO2 NWs, the charging potential reduced from 2.38 to 2.26 V with an improved capacity from 950 to 1327 mAh g−1, indicating the TiO2 NW has facilitated the discharge/charge reaction kinetics, resulting in an increased discharge capacity and lowered overpotential. The TiO2 NW/G electrode delivers a high-rate performance of 850 mAh g−1 at 2C (Figure 38c)429 and long cyclic stability with a capacity of 1053 mAh g−1 at 0.2C rate over 200 cycles, much higher compared to pure graphene electrode tested under the same conditions, demonstrating a great prospect for application in highperformance Li-S batteries. Considering that TiO2 belongs to a semiconductor with low electrical conductivity, it requires the careful control of adding the amount of the additives. Employing conducting TiN427 or nitrogen-doped titania NW to reduce Ti4+ or heat treatment of TiO2 with H2 gas to form the conductive TiO2−x phase
430−433 is effective in simultaneously achieving high conductive and strong chemical binding for sulfur species during cycling. Besides adding various additives, configuring interlayers between the separator and the sulfur cathode or coating interlayers on the separator has been demonstrated to have a great effect in mitigating the polysulfide dissolution and improving the cycling life of the sulfur cathode.413,434 Different from the commonly adopted vacuum-filtration methods to fabricate interlayers with thick and easily stacked structure, He et al. recently demonstrated a strategy to directly grow wellaligned, polar, and conductive Co9S8 arrays on a commercial Celgard separator (Co9S8−Celgard) as an efficient polysulfide barrier for Li-S batteries (Figure 38d).435 The vertical Co9S8 hollow nanowall arrays exhibit a thickness of about 10 μmwith a mass loading of only 0.16 mg cm−2 (Figure 38e). The Co9S8− Celgard separator has the advantages of large surface area, excellent mechanical stability, and strong chemical interactions with lithium polysulfides. By virtue of this unique structure, even with a pure sulfur cathode at a high sulfur loading of 5.6 mg cm−2, the battery exhibits an initial specific capacity of 1385
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AS
mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 1190 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles (Figure 38f) and an average capacity fade of only 0.039% per cycle after 1000 cycles at 1C. More importantly, the pouch cell employing the Co9S8-coated Celgard separator delivers 1185 mAh g−1 and remains stable after 30 cycles, demonstrating its promise for practical applications. Amore elaborate interlayer structure consisting of ZnO NWs on conducting frameworks was inspired by the brush-like membrane of cells for nutrient adsorption and applied for chemical adsorption of lithium polysulfides (Figure 38g).436 ZnO NWs grown on nickel (Ni) foam were first used as an interlayer to prove the concept for polysulfides adsorption, coated on the S/MWCNT composite cathode with an areal loading of about 3 mg cm−2, delivering a reversible capacity of 577.1 mAh g−1 with capacity retention of 81% after 500 cycles. To reduce the weight of Ni foam, an ultralight and thin interlayer by growing ZnO NWs on a CNF mat was designed and fabricated for practical application of Li-S batteries (Figure 38g,h). The well-organized nanostructured design allows the porous CNF backbone to provide a fast electron transfer and ion diffusion pathway and ZnO NWs to play an important role in trapping and reutilizing the polysulfides. With the help of the ZnO/CNF interlayer, the S/
MWCNT composite cathodemaintained a reversible capacity of 776 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles with only 0.05% average capacity loss per cycle at 1C (Figure 38i),436 displaying its promise as a multifunctional interlayer in rechargeable Li-S batteries. Following the above-discussed concepts, N-doped porous carbon NW437 or W18O49 NW/carbon black 438 modified separator, interwoven V2O5 NW/graphene nanoscroll hybrid interlayer,439 and sulfur electrode modified by electrodeposited polyaniline NWs440 orMnO2NWs
441 also demonstrated similar results with improved sulfur utilization and capacity retention. These results clearly demonstrate that the high electrical conductivity, strong interaction with lithium polysulfides, facilitated Li-ion transport, and catalyzing reduction/oxidation capability are crucial steps to realize high capacity, high Coulombic efficiency, and good cyclic stability. However, caution should be taken to not compromise the energy density of batteries after introducing the additional weight related to the inactive additives or interlayers. Therefore, attention should be paid to control the weight/percentages of these additives and the thickness/porosity of the interlayers without sacrificing the overall energy density of Li-S batteries.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AT

sections.heading: 7.4. Lithium Deposited on NWMaterials As a Dendrite-Free Anode
sections.text:
Lithium metal anodes are considered as the most promising anode candidates due to their high theoretical capacity (3860 mAh g−1 or 2061 mAh cm−3) and low potential (−3.04 V vs the standard hydrogen electrode),153 which are indispensable for building next-generation high-energy storage systems such as LiS and Li-air batteries. However, the high chemical reactivity of lithium metal anodes make them easily react with most organic electrolyte solvents to form an SEI layer on the surface of Li metal, leading to the consumption of electrolyte and low Coulombic efficiency.158,442,443 The hostless feature results in infinite relative volume change during cycling. Moreover, lithium dendrite formation during repeated charge/discharge cycles, which can eventually lead to an internal short circuit between the anode and cathode, causing severe safety issues, has plagued the development of long-lifetime lithium-metal-based batteries.444−446
A stable SEI formation on the Li metal surface is critical for achieving dendrite-free Li deposition/stripping because once a pinhole is formed in the SEI layer it will lead to locally enhanced Li-ion flux and promoted dendritic lithium growth during electrochemical cycling (Figure 39a).447 Besides, the continuously produced lithium dendrites consume Li and electrolyte through the formation/dissolution of SEI after repeated lithium plating/stripping processes, causing a low Coulombic efficiency. As the spatial inhomogeneity in charge distribution on the electrode surface is the root giving rise to Li dendrite growth, Liang et al. proposed a simple approach to mitigate this phenomenon by placing a 3D oxidized PAN nanofiber layer on top of the current collector to enable uniform ionic flux to conquer the above issues (Figure 39b). The electronically insulating PAN nanofiber mat effectively guides lithium plating into the 3D matrix. The polar oxygen-containing functional groups on the polymer nanofiber improve the affinity with Li metal and facilitate the electrolyte filtration and uptake. As a result, the coated lithium metal anode demonstrates a high average Coulombic efficiency of 97.4% over 120 cycles in etherbased electrolyte at a practical current density of 3mA cm−2 for a total areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2.447 Similar effects are observed by implementing 3D glass fiber with polar functional groups as a coating layer on the lithium anode, which uniformly distribute Li ions to realize a dendrite-free plating/stripping, verifying the validity of this facile strategy.448
Because the low current density leads to less lithium dendrites, the other important strategy to homogenize Li-ion flux and dissipate the current density is to employ high surface area electrode materials or current collectors to host lithium.442,449−451 For example, a 3D Cu current collector with fiber framework and high surface area was fabricated through self-assembling Cu(OH)2 fibers followed by dehydration and reduction (Figure 39c).449 This nanostructured design affords uniform electric field and charge distribution along the submicron Cu fiber skeleton, enabling homogeneous Li deposition with a relatively flat Li surface, as shown in Figure 39d. By virtue of this unique 3D current collector, the battery demonstrates low voltage hysteresis and stable cycling for more than 600 h without uncontrollable dendrite formation. By contrast, the preformed tiny Li dendrite in the planar current collector functions as a charge center to accumulate charge, amplifying the dendrite growth process (Figure 39e) and leading to irregular fluctuating voltage hysteresis and low cycling life.449 Some other studies employing a free-standing Cu−Ni core−
shell NW network (Figure 39f),452 copper NW network current collector,453 graphitized carbon fibers,454 Cu-CuO NW−Ni hybrid structure,455 and SiO2/SiC layer coated carbon-fiber paper456 have also exhibited great potential in reducing the effective current density and suppressing the growth of dendritic lithium with improved anode stability. Considering the infinite relative volume change of the Li metal anode related to its hostless nature, NW-based 3D scaffolds have been introduced as stable lithium host materials for Li stripping and plating.442,450,451 The 3D host materials with high surface area can effectively homogenize the ion flux, reduce local current density, and minimize the volume change of Li metal during cycling. Cui’s group is pioneering the development of a promising dendrite-free Li-coated PI anode by infusing molten lithium into the 3D PI matrix (Figure 39g).450 As the PI polymer is a lithiophobic material that cannot be wetted by molten lithium, a thin and conformal ZnO layer was coated via ALD on the PI fibers, which alters the surface to lithiophilicity due to the spontaneous reaction between ZnO and Li forming LixZn/Li2O in the matrix. The PI backbone confines lithium within the electrode with minimum volume change and uniform lithium stripping/plating. The obtained Li composite electrode with porous structure exhibits flat voltage profiles and stable cycling for more than 100 cycles at a high current density of 5 mA cm−2 in both carbonate and ether electrolyte, much better compared to bare Li foil electrodes with fluctuated and unstable cycling profile.450 This is a universal surface modification method that applies to many other Li-reacting materials to render 3D lithiophilic hosts such as an electrospun carbon fiber network modified with a silicon coating layer,451 coralloid carbon fibers electroplated with Ag,457 polyimide-coating layer with vertical nanoscale channels,458 ZnO-coated C-wood channels,459 and so on. Other than introducing a second phase mentioned above to react with molten Li to induce the Li metal into the porosity of 3D hosts, Liu and coauthors designed a porous and lithiophilic matrix through growing TiC/C core/shell NW arrays on the Ti6Al4V foil by a one-step CVD method.
460 Then the lithium metal can be directly loaded into the TiC/C skeleton via a simple thermal infusion process due to the lithiophilic property (Figure 39h). The advantages of this nanostructured host compared to bare lithium metal can be clearly visualized from the electric field distribution simulation. The Li-ion flux is easily concentrated on the protruding sites, leading to the unstable SEI and dendrite growth, which is caused by the tip effects with large electric field. On the contrary, no tip effect and uniform Li nucleation/growth can be observed when the TiC/CNW arrays are introduced to accommodate Li deposition, which can be ascribed to the lithiophilic NW networks homogenizing the electric field streamlines with a well-distributed Li ion.460 Therefore, a small hysteresis of less than 85 mV beyond 200 cycles at a high current density of 3 mA cm−2 was achieved for the TiC/C/Li composite anode. Moreover, good capacity retention and improved Coulombic efficiency can be obtained when the nanostructured Li anode couples with lithium iron phosphate or a sulfur cathode to assemble the full cells. Niu et al. also presented a stable Li−C anode for high-energy Li metal batteries by using amine-functionalized 3D mesoporous carbon fibers (Figure 39i).461 The strong interaction between Li metal and the functional groups on the carbon host favors a uniform Li deposition and a preferred nucleation of Li in the pores and/or the cavities, which produce a reversible and “self-smoothing” Li deposition on cycling. Benefiting from this self-smoothing
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AU
feature, the full cell displays excellent cycling performance. Although an ultimate solution was still not obtained, these progresses discussed above are valuable for the future exploration of stable host materials for Li-metal batteries.

sections.heading: 7.5. Summary
sections.text:
Despite that great research progress has been made by employing NW-based materials as additives, composite sulfur cathodes, and lithium anodes, the Li-S battery is still in its developing stage, and there are still a lot of challenges that need to be overcome before its practical applications. At present, most Li-S battery cathodes consist of carbonmaterials because of their high electrical conductivity, large surface area, rich porosity, and easy functionalization. The NW structure characteristics, including surface area, pore size, and pore volume, used in the sulfur electrode are critical factors that affect the performance of Li-S batteries. It is considered that NW materials with high surface area and abundant micro/mesopores are good candidates as sulfur electrodes because large reaction active sites can be provided to aid the electrochemical reactions, and more sulfur can be loaded. Suitable pore size and pore volume of NWs are also necessary for constructing electrolyte storage and diffusion pathways in the electrode of the Li-S battery. The design and development of novel 3D NW assembled materials with optimized channels that are helpful to transport Li+ and electrons is another way to improve the utilization of the sulfur cathode. Enough porous voids between and inside NWs are also necessary to provide space for the deposit of solid discharge products. Based on the understanding from theoretical calculations, exploring the conductive, strong interacting NW materials with similar polar properties of lithium polysulfides/ Li2S, identifying the mechanism of how binding energy
dominates the lithium diffusion, and catalytic conversion processes can open up new opportunities in the development of Li-S batteries. The addition of NW catalysts in the sulfur cathode, especially for Li2S/Li2S2, has the great prospect of reducing the overpotentials/energy barrier for the conversion of sulfur species. Therefore, understanding the mechanism and developing and screening advanced NW catalyst additives or substrates are promising directions for promoting the kinetics of Li-S batteries. Due to the safety concerns for the anode side, design of NW-based lithium anodes, such as construction of an interlayer or artificial layer on the surface of lithium to guide the uniform formation of a stable SEI film, building advanced 3D scaffolds or current collectors for diminishing volume change, and dissipating local current density have achieved a great impact and will be important research directions in the future. Prelithiated NW negative electrodes such as Si, Ge, and Sn NWs are another promising strategy. Pairing the high-performance sulfur cathode materials with a protected lithium anode or highcapacity lithiated lithium-freematerials to assemble full Li-S cells is a future developing direction for their practical applications. It is obviously not viable to address all the issues of Li-S batteries through a single strategy from NW-based sulfur cathodes or Li anodes. Instead, all the challenges should be considered as a systematic project with different approaches to ultimately realize the practical applications of Li-S batteries.

sections.heading: 8.1. Brief Introduction of Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Nowadays, our modern technology society requires large-scale use and storage of energy. As the most effective and practical
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AV
electrochemical energy storage devices, batteries and electrochemical SCs have attracted significant attention. Though the energy density of the SC is significantly lower than that of the battery, the SC has a longer cycling life of up to 105∼106 cycles and a higher power density compared to the battery as illustrated in Figure 40a.9,462 Moreover, SCs can achieve higher energy density (E) by increasing the charging voltage (V) and capacitance (C) according to the equation E = 0.5CV2. Thus, the SC with high power density and long cycle life has bridged the power density and energy density gap between traditional dielectric capacitors and batteries9,462 and therefore plays an increasingly important role in the future energy storage systems. SCs can be divided into two categories including an electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and Faradaic SCs (FS, also called pseudocapacitors). During the charging and discharging processes, there are no chemical changes and only physical electrostatic charge accumulation at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte in the EDLC as shown in Figure 40b, while fast redox reactions also occur in pseudocapacitors which may possibly cause the irreversible capacitance decay. As a result, pseudocapacitors can provide a higher capacitance than EDLCmaterials due to the redox reactions but possess a shorter
cycle life than the EDLCs due to their different mechanisms in storing charges.463

sections.heading: 8.2. Unique Characteristic of NWs for Supercapacitors
sections.text:
1D NW electrode materials have been extensively studied in SCs.464−467 The inherent 1Dmorphology of the NWs provides a fast pathway for efficient electron transportation, which is very beneficial to the improvement of the rate performance and power density of SCs.468 The larger length−diameter ratio of NWs brings a higher specific surface area, increases the contact area of the electrode interface/electrolyte, and then adsorbs a large number of electrolyte ions on the surface of the electrode, allowing the electrode reaction kinetics to proceed rapidly. In addition, carbon materials with high specific surface area based on the EDLC storage mechanism are faced with agglomeration at the nanometer level, and the 1D NW structure can solve this problem well and improve the specific surface area extensively.469−471 Pseudocapacitance NW materials could alleviate the volume expansion during cycling and then increase the stability of the electrode.472 The unique structural advantages of the NWs are effectively displayed in the SCs.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AW

sections.heading: 8.3. Carbon-Based NWs in EDLCs
sections.text:
Carbon material has become the main commercial electrode material due to its excellent cycling stability and low price.473−476 The energy storage process of carbon materials only involves the adsorption and accumulation of electrolyte ions. Therefore, the large specific surface area and developed pore structure are important indexes for electrochemical performance optimization. The 1D porous carbon NWs have large specific surface area and high porosity.477,478 Their 1D structure not only reduces the electron transport resistance but also maximizes the adsorbable area of electrolyte ions. CNTs and CNFs are the most typical carbon-based NWs.479−481
CNTs are one of the earliest researched carbon-based SC electrode materials.482 Its hollow structure could absorb a large number of electrolyte ions, and the graphitized wall is highly conductive for the effective transport of electrons, which shows excellent specific capacity and rate performance in the application of SCs. Frackowiak et al.483 obtained multiwall CNTs with a specific surface area of 410 m2 g−1 by using the CVD method, and the specific capacitance reached 137 F g−1. An et al.484 increased the specific capacitance to 180 F g−1, and the energy density reached 6.5 Wh kg−1 by using single-walled CNTs as electrode materials. However, the number of reports on CNT as SC electrode materials has been reduced in recent years due to the cost of CNTs and limited use of SC, and they are exploited as excellent conductive additives. CNFs are another of the most widely studied 1D carbon
materials based on their excellent flexibility and simple synthesis methods. CNFs overcome the limitations of the synthetic method of CNTs. In addition, the large specific surface area and structural stability of cross-linked CNFs are preferred for excellent electrode materials. Electrospinning has been widely studied as a common method to obtain nanofibers.485 Chen et al. developed an effective strategy to synthesize N-doped CNFs by using ZIF-8 as a precursor.66 The CNFs with high specific
surface area (418 m2 g−1) show large specific capacitance (307 F g−1 at 1 A g−1) and enhanced energy density (10.96 Wh kg−1). Furthermore, Yu’s group also obtained a series of CNFs by using Te NWs as templates and glucose as a carbon precursor.486−488 The mechanically robust monolith was obtained after hydrothermal treatment, which can be cut into any shape easily (Figure 41a).487 After removing the Te NWs, the CNFs were received and possess high yield and large specific surface area. After further coating polypyrrole (PPy) on CNFs and carbonization, the specific capacitance reached 202 F g−1, and the power density reached ∼90 kW kg−1 (Figure 41b−e).489 In addition, this research group also used bacterial cellulose as a precursor to obtain CNFs with heteroatom doping, whose energy density reached 7.76 Wh kg−1 (Figure 41f−i).490 These improvements to CNF give full play to its advantages in supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 8.4. NW Materials in Pseudocapacitors
sections.text:
Pseudocapacitors store charges through a reversible faradaic process at the surface/near surface of the active material.9,491−493 Metal oxides, metal sulfides, and conducting polymers have been commonly studied and classified as pseudocapacitive electrode materials.492,494,495 Compared with carbon materials, pseudocapacitive materials possess higher specific capacitance and energy density. However, they are mainly hindered by poor rate capability and inferior cycling stability. Owing to the high aspect ratio of NWs, pseudocapacitive electrodes with NWmorphologies are endowed with large electrode surface areas and efficient conducting pathways to facilitate fast redox reactions, resulting in better rate capability and improved cycling stability.
8.4.1. Metal Oxide/Sulfide-Based NWs in Pseudocapacitors. RuO2 is regarded as the ideal pseudocapacitive material owing to its excellent specific capacitance, high conductivity and stable cycling performances.496 However, the high cost of RuO2 nanomaterials has led to the exploration of
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AX
other low-cost yet poorly conductive metal oxides such asMnO2 and Co3O4.
497−501 Designing metal oxide NW electrodes can enhance the conducting pathways for fast faradaic reactions, resulting in excellent electrochemical performance. For example, Yang and co-workers reported MnO2 NWs grown on carbon fiber clothes (Figure 42a) with a high specific capacitance of 150 mF cm−2 at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and an outstanding rate capability of 73.6% at 10 mA cm−2.500 Also, Rakhi and coworkers successfully synthesized Co3O4 NWs with brush-like morphology which displayed a high specific capacitance of 1525 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 in a three-electrode configuration.501 Furthermore, the electrochemical performance of metal oxide NW electrodes can be improved by designing hybrid core− shell/coaxial NW structures, pseudocapacitive/carbon material composites, or metal doping.502−505 This enhancement in electrochemical performance arises from the enhanced conductivity and enlarged electrode surface areas. For example, Zhou and co-workers successfully constructed a CoO@PPy core−shell structure (Figure 42b) which presented an ultrahigh capacitance of 2223 F g−1 at 1 mA cm−2 (Figure 42c, inset) and excellent capacitance retention.504 A hierarchical Co3O4@ PPy@MnO2 coaxial NW array (Figure 42d and e) on nickel foam presented an almost 2-fold increase in capacitance compared to the Co3O4 NW core.
502 Also, Xia et al. successfully achieved a 2-fold increase in capacitance and enhancement of the rate capability by doping Ag nanoparticles into MnO2 NWs.505
In recent studies, binary metal oxides such as NiCo2O4, ZnCo2O4, and MnCo2O4 have been preferred as SC electrodes over mono metal oxides owing to their superior electrochemical activity.506 For instance, a mesoporous NiCo2O4 NW array grown on a carbon cloth substrate (Figure 42f) reported by Shen et al. exhibited a high specific capacitance of 1283 F g−1 at 1 A
g−1, an excellent rate capability of 79% at 20 A g−1, and stable cycling performance up to 5000 cycles.250 Also, a high capacitance of 2244 F g−1 was attained by a NiCo2O4@PPy NW array due to the synergistic effect between the two pseudocapacitive electrodes.507 Comparatively, transition metal sulfides exhibit better conductivities than their oxide counterparts, and thus materials such as CoS2, NiCo2S4, and ZnCo2S4 NW electrodes have been synthesized to realize high capacitances.508,509 Li et al. successfully synthesized a Ni−Co sulfide NW array on a nickel foam substrate through a hydrothermal and ion-exchange method which displayed high areal and gravimetric capacitances of 6.0 F cm−2 and 2415 F g−1, respectively.495
8.4.2. Conductive Polymer NWs in Pseudocapacitors. Conducting polymer (PPy, PANI, and PEDOT) pseudocapacitive materials are characterized by high specific capacitance and excellent conductivity.9,491 However, poor ion mobility within conducting polymer electrodes results in high bulk resistance and poor cycling stability. Designing 1D conducting polymer NW arrays on current collector substrates ensures the effective utilization of active materials owing to the short diffusion length in NWs and reduces the overall resistance by eliminating the use of a binder (Figure 43a).510 For example, Wang et al. successfully synthesized 50 nm thick PANI NWs (Figure 43b) on conductive substrates using a facile one-step galvanostatic deposition method.511 The deposited PANI NW arrays exhibited a high specific capacitance of 950 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and retained 82% of the initial capacitance at a high current density of 40 A g−1 (Figure 43c). The cycling stability as well as the capacitances of conducting polymer NW electrodes can also be effectively improved by compositing with highly conductive carbon nanomaterials. Liu et al. improved the cycling performance of PANI (from 20 to
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AY
95%) and PPy (25 to 85%) NWs by encapsulating with an ∼5 nm carbonaceous shell.512 Xu et al. successfully synthesized 1D PANI NWs on a 2D graphene nanosheet hierarchical nanocomposite with superior electrochemical performance in comparison with the individual graphene sheets and PANI NWs (Figure 43d and e).513 Also, Yu et al. successfully achieved highly dispersed PPy NWs on graphene nanosheets using an in situ synthesis method which presented a high capacitance of 434.7 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and 83% capacitance retention at 20 A g−1 (Figure 43f).514

sections.heading: 8.5. NW Materials in Hybrid Capacitors
sections.text:
As mentioned before, SCs suffer from much lower energy density compared to LIBs.515,516 To promote the energy density
of SC, one strategy is to construct hybrid capacitors. The hybrid capacitors (HCs) are fabricated from a capacitor type electrode material as the cathode and a battery type electrode material as the anode including insertion-type materials. HCs could be classified into two kinds based on the electrolyte: one is aqueous, and the other is the nonaqueous system.517,518 Aqueous HCs are renowned for a higher ionic concentration and lower resistance and cause great attention.491 For example, Harilal et al.519 reported that the CuO−Co3O4 nanocomposite NWs show a high-rate capability in the aqueous alkaline electrolyte. However, they are enslaved to a shorter working voltage which limited their energy density. In contrast, the nonaqueous system (Figure 44a) can deliver a higher energy density which has emerged and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
AZ
become a hot research topic like Li-ion and Na-ion capacitors (LICs and SICs).520
Stabilized and fast intercalation/deintercalation of cations is necessary for battery type electrodes.521 As active electrodes, nanostructured materials especially NWs can promote their high-rate properties.522 NWs are of great interest for full utilization of the merit of materials in energy storage applications.523 The shorter ion diffusion length, facile electron conduction channel, as well as ease of electrolyte diffusion would greatly benefit the electrochemical process.520,524,525 Such a distinct nanostructure that merged all these virtues is deemed as best mate with HCs which has been verified by many works. Wang et al.525 reported a T-Nb2O5 NW structure with ultrathin carbon coating, which exhibits high-rate Li+ storage ability for LICs. Que et al.526 built the 3D structure with ultralong NWs and rooftop networks. The LIC assembled by a hydrogen titanate (HTO) NW array (NWAs) anode and activated carbon (AC) cathode showed superior rate capability and ultralong lifespan (Figure 44b,c). Xu et al.527 fabricated LICs with WO3−x/N-doped carbon NWs exhibiting an ultrahigh-energy density of 195.58 Wh kg−1 with 90.7% retention over 6000 cycles (Figure 44d−f). All these results indicate that the NW structure materials are promising for next-generation electrochemical energy storage.493

sections.heading: 8.6. Summary
sections.text:
We have summarized and discussed the application of various NWs in SCs. Carbon NWs based on the physical adsorption mechanism are still the first choice for commercial electrode materials, and the cycling stability of the pseudocapacitance materials needs to be improved. Therefore, hybrid capacitors are the most suitable electrochemical devices for further development at present. The low energy density of the SCs still limits its long-term development. In the past few years, the research of electrode materials has excessively focused on its specific surface area, while the larger specific surface area could only bring unilateral advantages. The volumetric energy density of the device will be greatly reduced. How to design the coordination between the specific surface area and pore size distribution of porous electrode materials of NWs and the transport kinetics of solvated ions will be the focus of future research. In addition, the diffusion mechanism of dissolved ions in electrolyte and the regulation of the electrochemical window should be paid more attention. Considering all these factors, 1D NW electrode materials outperformmost candidate materials for SCs due to their unique properties including: (1) the large length−diameter ratio leads to high surface area for ion absorption/desorption and abundant active sites for faradaic pseudocapacitance and is more beneficial for surface modification or loading to further improve the performance; (2) high conductivity cross-linked network greatly increases the charge transfer rate and reduces the mass diffusion length, leading to the excellent rate capability of NW materials; (3) the cross-linked NWs avoid agglomeration of the nanomaterial (such as spheres, sheets, etc.) and accelerate the infiltration of electrolytes as well as the absorption/desorption of ions. Such advantages lead to high specific capacitance, good rate capability, and cycle stability of NWs in SCs. Particularly, the lower energy density as the core issue in SCs can be improved by organic electrolytes with a high-voltage window (3.5 ∼ 5.0 V). NW electrodes with stable structure and good conductivity can endure the high working voltage, and the cross-linked porous structure effectively alleviates the high viscosity and slow
diffusion rate of the organic electrolytes. Therefore, NW electrode materials have a certain competitiveness and broad development prospect in the SC electrode materials studied at present and are expected to be applied commercially.

sections.heading: 9. CONCLUSIONS AND OUTLOOK
sections.text:
In this paper, we have comprehensively reviewed the recent progress of NW fabrication strategies and discussed the unique features of NW electrodes for in situ characterizations and electrochemical energy storage in the fields of LIBs, SIBs, Li-S batteries, SCs, etc. The advantages of the NW electrodes over the conventional bulk materials in overcoming the critical issues have been well elucidated and demonstrated in various energy storage devices. In spite of the many significant advancements that have been achieved in both synthesis and applications of NWs, their deployment is still falling behind the requirements. A number of challenges remain, and substantial room exists for their future development to propel practical applications of NWs-based energy storage devices including: (1) The yield of NWs for scalable fabrication for the practical applications is still insufficient, and the production of NWs with various structures (such as hierarchical, branched, core−shell, etc.) is still costly. Therefore, large-scale fabrication of NWs with low cost, desirable performance, and controllable structures will be necessary. (2) As the properties of NWs are related to their shape and size, development of an efficient synthesis method for precise control of the morphology and size is required. Exploring methods for controllable synthesis of multielement or multiphase NWs would grant the materials with new properties and expand material diversity and their applications. Innovations in the development of novel 3D electrode materials with fast ion and electron transfer kinetics is a promising approach to realize high-energy and -power densities. (3) Design and rational assembly of complex NW structures is another direction worth exploration because they could offer more choices to tune the electrochemical performance compared to single-structured NW electrode materials. Nanostructured design, such as coaxial, triaxial, hierarchical heterostructures, core−shell, multishell NW, and NW arrays, can be applied to further optimize the electrochemical performance of energy storage devices. (4) Because NW structure increases the external surface area and the risk of more undesirable side reactions occurring at the electrolyte−electrode interface, designing materials with a protective interface (such as carbon coating) or selecting suitable electrolytes within their stable window are beneficial for forming a realizable SEI layer. Other strategies such as hierarchical, branched, or secondary particle-based structures can alleviate this effect. (5) NWs can not only be used as electrode materials in the storage systems, NW-based 3D current collectors, or hosts, either in arrays or porous structure, but also provide increased surface area for active material deposition/storage and electrolyte infiltration arising from the porosity and spacing between NWs, thus enabling fast kinetics and stable energy storage and release. (6) NW electrode materials with optimized pore size and volume can maximize active material content/mass loading to achieve high energy/volumetric energy density battery/SC performance. Besides a thick electrode, assembling of ultrathin NW network electrodes offers a new paradigm for designing transparent energy storage devices.528 Hierarchical pore NW
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00326 Chem. Rev. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
BA
structure will facilitate the transport of the lithium ion to the active surface and provide enough room for accommodating active materials at the same time. (7) Building novel electrode structure or battery configurations offers a promising avenue for designing multifunctional energy storage devices. For example, a single NW-based hybrid electrochemical device was designed by integrating the PANI cathode and Ni−Sn anode into a solid electrolyte-packaged single NW, which is helpful for better understanding Li-ion electrochemistry at the nanoscale and shows the potential of realizing miniature energy storage device.529 Considering safety and reliability, the ultimate goal is to develop compatible, high ionic conductivity NW-based electrolytes with high-performance NW-assembled cathodes and anodes to build all-NWbased devices. (8) The development of advanced nanoscale tools, especially in situ and in operando characterization techniques, is critical for a deep understanding of the structural evolution of materials and mechanisms involved in the electrochemistry processes and further guiding the design of better electrode materials for highperformance energy storage devices. NWs provide a good platform to investigate the basic scientific issues and reveal the reaction mechanism based on the developed in situ or in operando characterization techniques. In turn, the characterization techniques will enrich the capability in understanding the properties of NWs from a spatial, temporal, and atomic level. (9) Theoretical calculation and simulation are important to predict and gain a full picture of the thermal dynamics and kinetics of NW electrode materials during lithiation and delithiation, which can be combined with the experimental measurement. Currently developed machine learning capability has pointed out a new direction for the discovery of new NW materials as well as prediction of the possible properties. Despite the above-mentioned challenges that remain, the unique physical and chemical properties of NW electrodes, together with various synthetic methods for controlled NW morphology and sizes, provide an exciting opportunity to build advanced electrochemical energy storage devices for practical applications.

In 2005 he joined Stanford as an Assistant Professor. In 2010 he was promoted to an Associate Professor with tenure. His current research is on nanomaterials for energy storage, solar cells, environment, and biology. He is an Associate Editor ofNano Letters. He is a codirector of the Bay Area Photovoltaics Consortium and Battery500 Consortium. He has founded Amprius, Inc., 4C Air Inc., and EEnovate Technology Inc. He was elected as a Fellow of Royal Society of Chemistry in 2015, a Fellow of Materials Research Society in 2016, and a Fellow of Electrochemical Society in 2018.

metadata.abstractText: Nanomaterials provide many desirable properties for electrochemical energy storage devices due to their nanoscale size effect, which could be significantly different from bulk or micron-sized materials. Particularly, confined dimensions play important roles in determining the properties of nanomaterials, such as the kinetics of ion diffusion, the magnitude of strain/stress, and the utilization of active materials. Nanowires, as one of the representative one-dimensional nanomaterials, have great capability for realizing a variety of applications in the fields of energy storage since they could maintain electron transport along the long axis and have a confinement effect across the diameter. In this review, we give a systematic overview of the state-of-the-art research progress on nanowires for electrochemical energy storage, from rational design and synthesis, in situ structural characterizations, to several important applications in energy storage including lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, sodium-ion batteries, and supercapacitors. The problems and limitations in electrochemical energy storage and the advantages in utilizing nanowires to address the issues and improve the device performance are pointed out. At the end, we also discuss the challenges and demonstrate the prospective for the future development of advanced nanowire-based energy storage devices.
